Subject: Statistics for Datascience Case study Message:

Dear Students,

Case study should be any real world problem which is supposed to solve by using any open source language and tools.

1. Maximum number of students per batch only 2 member.

2.Take any real world dataset form kaggle or UCI repository.

3.Analyze the dataset 

4. Pre-process the dataset

5. Do the feature selection/reduction/extraction.

6.Do proper classification using statistical algorithms

7. Print the results.

Subject: Syllabus Message:

DBMS Theory Syllabus

Subject: Unit1 Slides Message:

Unit1:

Advantages of using DBMS approach; Data models, schemas and instances; DBMS component module Threeschema

architecture and data independence; Database languages; Classification of Database Management

systems

Using High-Level Conceptual Data Models for Database Design; An Example Database Application; Entity

Types, Entity Sets, Attributes and Keys; Relationship types, Relationship Sets, Roles and Structural Constraints;

Weak Entity Types; ER Diagrams, Naming Conventions and Design Issues; Relationship types of degree higher

than two

Subject: Unit2 Slides for MSE-1 Message:

Unit 2 Syllabus for MSE I

Relational database design using ER to relational mapping; Relational Model Concepts; Relational Model

Constraints and Relational Database Schemas; Update Operations, Transactions and dealing with constraint

violations;

Subject: Portions for MSE 1 Message:

Dear Students,

                 Below is the portions for MSE-1, related topic slides for reference is being shared. All the Best  

UNIT I

Advantages of using DBMS approach; Data models, schemas and instances; DBMS component module Threeschema

architecture and data independence; Database languages; Classification of Database Management

systems

Using High-Level Conceptual Data Models for Database Design; An Example Database Application; Entity

Types, Entity Sets, Attributes and Keys; Relationship types, Relationship Sets, Roles and Structural Constraints;

Weak Entity Types; ER Diagrams, Naming Conventions and Design Issues; Relationship types of degree higher

than two

UNIT II 

Relational database design using ER to relational mapping; Relational Model Concepts; Relational Model

Constraints and Relational Database Schemas; Update Operations, Transactions and dealing with constraint

violations.

Subject: ML lab A2 Batch Instructions for 06-01-2022 Message:

Dear ML A2 Batch Students

Today lab internals for ML is canceled.

The next date will be informed shortly.

Today you have to implement the PCA on the iris dataset.

PCA was completed in Monday and Wednesday classes, with instructions on how to implement PCA in python from scratch.

The PPT is also updated in LMS. For any clarifications(or explanations if required)let me know through WhatsApp message.

The deadline to implement PCA and upload to git is 06-01-2022 6 pm.


Program: Use IRIS data set and perform the PCA on the dataset. Examine the first 2 principal components of X. Create a scatter plot with each of the 150 rows of X projected onto the first two principal components. In other words, the horizontal axis should be first principal component, the vertical axis should be second principal component.

Subject: ML A1 Batch instructions for 08/01/2022 Message:

Dear Students

Execute the logistic regression algorithm (using all the preprocessing steps discussed in theory class) with the student-university dataset.

The deadline to upload the logistic regression program is 08/01/2022 6.00 pm.

Also, implement PCA on the iris dataset and plot the two principal components.

The deadline to upload the PCA program to GitHub is 09/01/2022 6.00 pm.

Program (PCA): Use IRIS data set and perform the PCA on the dataset. Examine the first 2 principal components of X. Dear Students

Follow these instructions carefully and ensure that all instructions are followed.

1) Record the presentation of the 3rd phase(final) project presentation.

6) If panel members/guides have any queries, then they will post the same in the announcement section and you have to answer them

Subject: 8th Semester Project Work-reg Message:

Dear Students

Please read the below points carefully regarding your 8th-semester project work.

1) 8th Semester project work is for 100 marks(CIE-50 Marks and SEE-50 Marks)

2) 50 Marks CIE will be evaluated as 

        a) A Presentation in the month of May which will be evaluated for 25 Marks

        b) Thesis(Final Report) submission by June end which will be evaluated for 25 Marks. The report                  has to be prepared using LaTex, for which the training session will be arranged shortly.

3) Publishing your project work as a research paper in reputed journals is mandatory for all the project              batches, without which you will be not allowed to submit your thesis. Contact your respective                                  guides regarding this.

4) There will be a project exhibition(Inspark) conducted at the end of the semester where you have to showcase your completed projects to your juniors, faculty, Deans, Principal, and others. Industry experts and NMIT ISE alumni will be evaluating your projects and the top 3 projects will be rewarded.


Kindly read all the points carefully, complete your project work(execution and testing) in all aspects and get ready for the project presentation.

Subject: RCC DETAILING LABORATORY - SYLLABUS COPY Message:

RCC DETAILING  LABORATORY

Course Code

18CVL67

 

Credits

1

Hours/Week (L-T-P)

0+0+2(L+T+P)

 

CIE Marks

50

Total Hrs

26P

 

SEE Marks

50

Exam Hrs

03

 

Course Type

Core Laboratory

COURSE OUTCOMES

Pre-requisites:

The student would have to be well-versed with Theory of Concrete Technology and Transportation Engineering -I.

Course Outcomes:

After completion of the course, students will be able to,

1.  prepare working drawings of RCC Structural components 

2.  prepare working drawings of Steel Structural components

TEACHING METHODOLOGY

● Blackboard teaching/Power Point Presentation (If needed)

● Demonstration of experiments by teaching faculty

● Conduction of experiments by groups of students in the lab

● Regular review of students by asking viva questions based on experiments covered

COURSE CONTENTS

List of experiments

Module 1 Detailing of RCC Structures with bar bending Schedules  - (20 hours)

1. Beams – Simply supported, Cantilever and Continuous, T-Beam.

2. Column-Detailing (Rectanular, Square and Circular Cross sections and Longitudinal Section)

3. Slab – One way, two way and One-way continuous.

4. Staircase – Doglegged , Open ,

5. Footings -Isolated, Combined Footing

6. Cantilever Retaining wall.

7. Counter Fort Retaining wall.

8. Circular Water Tank, Rectangular Water Tank.

REFERENCE BOOKS

Exp.1 to 8

Reinforced Concrete Design - Third Edition Paperback – 1 July 2017 by Devdas Menon

COURSE ASSESSMENT METHOD:

Record + Observation                : 30 marks

Viva Voce                                   :05marks

Test                                             :15 marks

SEE - Final Exam                      :50 Marks

Subject: CNS Assignment -1 Message:

Cryptography and Network Security

Date: 9/5/2022


SUBMIT BY 12/05/2022


Assignment-1

1.      Describe in detail the Playfair Cipher. Encrypt the Plaintext NITTE MEENAKSHI INSTITUE OF TECHNOLOGY using the key YELAHANKA

2.      Describe the technique of Hill Cipher. Break Hill Cipher with the plaintext-Ciphertext pair (FRIDAY, PQCFKU)

3.      Explain with an example why one-time PAD is said to be unbreakable.

4.      When the PT-109 American Boat, under the command of Lieutenant John.F.Kennedy , was sunk by a Japanese Destroyer, a message was received at an Australian Wireless Station in Playfair code

        KXJEY    UREBE      ZWEHE      WRYTU     HEYFS

        KREHE   GOYFI      WTTTU      OLKSY        CAJPO

The key used was “ROYAL NEWZEALAND NAVY”, Decrypt the Message.

5.      Encrypt the Plaintext 00000000 using the key 1111111111 using S-DES. Show all the calculations and the result.

Subject: TIM Unit 1. Message:

1. Compare Power and Distribution Transformers.

2. Compare Voltage and Current Transformers.

3. Why an Voltage transformer should not be operated in short circuited condition and Why a Current Transformer should not be open circuited.

4. Explain the principle of Variable frequency transformer.

5. Prove that there is saving of copper in an autotransformer. What are the applications of Auto transformer?

6. Explain the phasor diagram of single phase Transformer under i) No load condition and ii) under loaded condition supplying different types of load.

7. Show that the transformer is a constant flux machine.

8. Derive the approximate equivalent circuit of Transformer referred to Primary and secondary side.

Subject: Project Report, Plagiarism, Research paper and Presentation-reg Message:

Dear Students,

  • The final report has to be submitted after the presentation.
  • So, start preparing the report contents.
  • Report content guidelines are attached as topic in LMS project work course page. Follow the instructions clearly.
  • Students are expected to prepare their thesis in Latex according to the guidelines and template attached below.
  • Link for accessing thesis Template:

https://www.overleaf.com/latex/templates/nitte-meenakshi-institute-of-technology-nmit-thesis-latex-template/tkfpsjsgbbmd

  • Before taking the final printout, report contents have to be checked for plagiarism. 
  • As per institute and department standard the similarity index should be less than 20%.
  • Please note the following points before sending a project report/thesis for plagiarism check.  Send the reports to your guides and they in turn will send to nmit library for plagiarism check.
  •                Mention Title of the article, Name of the Author, Guide, USN.        
  •                No Header, Footer.        
  •               Exclude- Cover page, Declaration, Certificate, Table of Content, List of Figures, Abstract etc..
  • There will be no fee for two plagiarism checks.


  • A talk on how to use latex for preparing the thesis is arranged on 26/05/2022 for 1 hour, online. The talk will be delivered by Dr. ManojKumar. It is mandatory for everybody to attend as it helps you to understand how to use Latex.

Subject: Syllabus of Precast and Prefabricated Structures-18CVE466 Message:

PRECAST AND PREFABRICATED STRUCTURES

Course Code

18CVE466

 

Credits

3

Hours/Week (L-T-P)

3+0+0(L+T+P)

 

CIE Marks

50

Total Hrs

39L

 

SEE Marks

50

Exam Hrs

03

 

Course Type

Program Elective

COURSE OUTCOMES

After completion of the course, students will be able to,

1.      Summaries Precast construction methods(L2)

2.      Explain Precast Concrete Production Techniques(L4)

3.      Design prefabricated Elements.(L4)

4.      Choose suitable technique and equipment in precast construction(L2)

TEACHING METHODOLOGY

●                  Blackboard teaching/PowerPoint presentations (if needed)

●                  Regular review of students by asking questions based on topics covered in the class

COURSE CONTENTS

UNIT -1- (9L+0T+0P)

Modular Construction --- Basic module, Planning and Design of modular grid system, National Building Code Specifications, Standardization, Dimensions of Products, Preferred Dimensions and Sizes, tolerances and Deviations, Layout and Process.

UNIT -2- (7L+0T+0P)

Classification of Prefabricates--- Foundations, Beams and Columns, Roof and Roof panels, Wall panels, Box fabricates Erection and assembly.

Pre-casting and Pre-fabricating Techniques---- Planning, Production and erection of industrial Structures, Space structures and prestressed   pre-cast elements.

UNIT -3- (8L+0T+0P)

Precast Concrete Production Techniques: Forms and moulds for various materials, manufacturing methods—Pressed casting extrusion method, Vacuum process, spinning process, Hot concrete process, mix designs adopted, Large panel construction, Box systems, Lift slab systems.

UNIT -4- (8L+0T+0P)

Design of prefabricated elements-  Lift points, joints in elements, Design of joints to transfer axial forces, moments, shear forces. Concepts of design principles- case studies

UNIT -5- (7L+0T+0P)

Site Infrastructure---Equipment, Horizontal and Vertical transportation, In-situ manufacture and preparation, Fabrication, Storage and Assembly, curing methods of Prefabricates.

TEXT BOOKS

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Koncz  Tihamer, “Manual of Precast Concrete Construction” Vol 1,2,3, Buverlag GMBH, Wiesbaden and Berlin.

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Kim S. Elliott, Precast Concrete Structures, Second Edition, CRC Press

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Nirajan Kumar Jha, Precast Concrete Technology (Future Of Civil Engineering), Blue Rose Publishers

REFERENCE BOOKS

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Lewiciki, Bohdan, “Building with large Prefabricates”, Elsevier Publishing Company, London 1966.

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

National Building Code {part –VI, Prefabrication and systems building}, Bureau of Indian Standards.

ONLINE RESOURCES

Link

Masonry units, materials, types

https://sites.google.com/a/mitr.iitm.ac.in/iitmcivil/ce2330

Strength and Stability of concentrically loaded

https://nptel.ac.in/courses/105105108/38

Stress reduction and shape reduction

https://nptel.ac.in/courses/112104193/

Effective height of walls and columns

https://nptel.ac.in/courses/105105108/37

Wall carrying axial load

https://nptel.ac.in/courses/105101085/9

Design of load bearing masonry

https://nptel.ac.in/courses/105105165/

Composite wall-beam elements

https://nptel.ac.in/courses/105102090/16

COURSE ASSESSMENT METHOD:

 

Continuous Internal Evaluation (CIE):

1.      Three internals tests (each 30 marks) are conducted, average of best two tests marks will be considered.

2.      Minimum two Assignments/Model making - evaluated through rubrics for 10 marks. Average of two will be considered.

3.      Tutorial classes and assessment are carried out/Surprise quiz tests are conducted and evaluated for 10 marks. Average of these two will be considered.

 

Semester End Examination (SEE):

1.      Two Questions are to be set from each unit, carrying 20 Marks each.

2.      Students have to answer 5 questions selecting one full question

Subject: Course Backup Message:

Dear Teachers

Please take the backup of your complete course page from Moodle.

Follow the steps as below:

1. Goto the course page

2. Click the settings icon at the top right

3.Click on "backup"
4. Choose the items to be backed up in the backup settings page

5. click on Jump to Final Step 

6. It will take few minutes to create a backup file. Please wait for the response from the system until you see a message "backup created successfully"

7. Press "continue"

8. You will see the backup file with an extension 'mbz".

9. Click on "download" and the file will be saved in your local machine.

10. Keep this file safely. In case of any restoration required, you can restore the course from any course page. 


For further support, contact your department coordinator

Regards

Admin  LMS

Subject: Syllabus of Aerodynamics 2 (18AE52) Message:

UNIT I

Introduction to Two-Dimensional Panel Methods: Non-lifting flows over arbitrary bodies, source panel method, lifting flows over arbitrary bodies, vortex panel method, some examples

Incompressible Flows Over Finite Wings: Downwash, Induced drag, vortex filament, the Biot-Savart Law, Prandtl’s lifting line theory and its limitations, Elliptic lift distribution.

10 Hours

UNIT II

Subsonic linearized flow over airfoils: Full velocity potential equation, linearized velocity potential equation and boundary condition, Prandtl-Glauert compressibility correction.

Effects of Compressibility: Basics of speed of sound, Mach waves, Normal shock waves, Oblique shock waves, Expansion fan, Prandtl – Meyer expansion, Critical Mach number; Drag- divergence Mach number, Sound Barrier, Transonic area rule.

10 Hours

UNIT III

Applications of Finite Wing Theory: Simplified horse-shoe vortex model, formation flight, influence of downwash on tail plane, ground effects.

Bodies of Revolution: Introduction to slender body theory, cylindrical coordinates, boundary conditions, pressure coefficient, Subsonic flow past a axially symmetric body at zero incidence and solution for a slender cone.

10 Hours

UNIT IV

Swept Wings and High-Lift Systems: Introduction to sweep effects, swept wings, pressure coefficient, typical aerodynamic characteristics, Subsonic and Supersonic leading edges. Introduction to high-lift systems, flaps, leading-edge slats and typical high - lift characteristics.

09Hours

UNIT V

Viscous Flows:

Derivation of Navier-Stokes equation for two-dimensional flows, boundary approximations, laminar boundary equations and boundary conditions, Blasius solution, qualitative features of boundary layer 

flow under pressure gradients, Integral method, aspects of transition to turbulence, turbulent boundary layer properties over a flat plate at low speeds.

09 Hours

Text Books:

1.       Anderson, Jr. J.D. “Fundamentals of Aerodynamics”, Tata McGraw-Hill Publishing Co. Ltd., New Delhi, 2007 (Special Indian Edition).

2.       H.W. Liepmann and A. Roshko, “Elements of Gas Dynamics”

3.       Schlichting, H, “Boundary layer theory”, McGraw Hill, New York 2004

Reference:

4.       Bertin, John J., “Aerodynamics for Engineers”. Pearson Education Inc., 2002.

5.       White, F.M., “Fluid Mechanics”, Mc Graw Hill Inc. New York, 1986

6.       Houghton E.L and Carpenter P.W. “Aerodynamics for Engineering Students”, CBS Publications and Distributors, 8 1993 (4th Edition).

7.      Anderson, Jr. J.D. “Introduction to Flight”, Tata McGraw-Hill Publishing Co. Ltd., New Delhi, 2007(Special Indian Edition).

Subject: GENTLE REMINDER Message:

Dear Students this is Gentle Reminder to  Carryout UNIT 1 Activities 

1. RECENT-ADVANCEMENTS IN THE TOPICS- Teachers should identify few fast learners in the class/subject and for each UNIT, those students should study the recent advancements in that UNIT’s topic by reading recent Conferences/Journals/Newsletters etc., and present it to the class, make a report (Softcopy in PDF format) and circulate it to all the students of the class.(Note: For each Unit different set of students can be identified and can be considered for LA1/LA2 component).

2. BLOOM’S TAXONOMY- After each UNIT, the identified students should prepare question bank with relevant Bloom’s Taxonomy, under the guidance of the subject teacher, present and discuss those questions in the class. Also, should prepare answers to those questions and circulate them in the class. (NOTE- It is not necessary to choose these questions for MSEs)

3. PEER-LEARNING ACTIVITY

MENTOR-MENTEE Mapping (FAST-LEARNERS: SLOW LEARNERS)- Teachers should identify fast learners (who will be the MENTORS) in the class and assign Max. 5 Slow learners (who will be the MENTEES) to them. The Mentors should teach the Mentees during their free time and conduct at least one QUIZ for 10 Marks, immediately after the completion of each UNIT, and submit the Class conducted details, Attendance details and QUIZ conducted details in PDF format to the subject teacher after each UNIT.

Subject: Multi-Stage Optimized Machine Learning Framework for Network Intrusion Detection Message:

Cyber-security garnered significant attention due to the increased dependency of individuals and organizations on the Internet and their concern about the security and privacy of their online activities. Several previous machine learning (ML)-based network intrusion detection systems (NIDSs) have been developed to protect against malicious online behavior. Here we propose a novel multi-stage optimized MLbased NIDS framework that reduces computational complexity while maintaining its detection performance.

Subject: Syllabus Message:





Irrigation Engineering and Hydraulic Structures

Course Code

18CV76

 

Credits

04

Hours/Week (L-T-P)

03+0+0(L+T+P)

 

CIE Marks

50

Total Hrs

39L+0T+0P

 

SEE Marks

50

Exam Hrs

03

 

Course Type

Engg Core

COURSE OUTCOMES

Course Outcomes:

After completion of the course, students will be able to,

1.      Understand the systems of irrigation, suggest suitable irrigation practices and compute crop water requirements. (L2)

2.      Design unlined and lined channels in alluvial soils and cross drainage works. (L4)

3.      Understand concept of planning, designing and operational requirements of storage reservoir. (L3)

4.      Analyze and design hydraulic structures like Weirs, Earthen dam, Gravity dam and spillways. (L4)

TEACHING METHODOLOGY

· Blackboard teaching/PowerPoint presentations (if needed)

· Regular review of students by asking questions based on topics covered in the class

COURSE CONTENTS

UNIT -1- (7L+0T+0P)

Introduction: Benefits and ill effects of irrigation. Sources of water for irrigation, Method of irrigation: flow irrigation, Lift Irrigation, Bhandhara Irrigation, Drip Irrigation and Sprinkler Irrigation. Potential and development of irrigation in India.               

Irrigation and water requirements of crops: Definition of duty, Delta and Base period, Relationship between Duty, Delta and Base period, Factors affecting duty of water. Irrigation efficiency, Frequency of irrigation.      

UNIT -2- (8L+0T+0P)

Canals: Definition. Types of canals, Alignment of canals. Design of canals by Kennedy’s and Lacey’s methods. Lined canals: types of lining, selection of types of lining, economics of lining, design of lined canals.

Cross drainage works:  types- selection of suitable type of CD works- aqueduct and Syphon aqueduct- determination of maximum flood discharge and waterway for drain, fluming of canal-uplift pressure on underside of barrel roof and at the floor of the culvert- design of bank connections.                

UNIT -3- (8L+0T+0P)

Reservoirs: Definitions. Investigation for reservoir sites. Storage zones. Determination of storage capacity and yield of a reservoir using mass curve.

Diversion Works: Definition. Layout. Types of weirs and Barrages. Design of Impermeable floors – Bligh’s and Lane’s theories – Simple design problems.

UNIT -4- (8L+0T+0P)

Dams: Introduction, Types of dams, Factors Affecting Selection of Dam, Modes of Failure of dam.

Gravity dams: Definition. Forces acting on a Gravity dam. Elementary and practical profile. Low and high gravity dams. Simple analysis problems, Principal stresses. Drainage galleries.

UNIT -5- (8L+0T+0P)

Earthen dams: Introduction. Types of earthen dams. Failure of earthen dams. Preliminary design. Drainage arrangements. Phreatic line.                   

Spillways: Definition. Types of Spillways. Design Principles for an Ogee Spillway. Energy dissipaters: Types and introduction to IS Stilling basins (No design problems).

Subject: Syllabus Message:

GEOTECHNICAL ENGINEERING – I

Course Code

18CV55

 

Credits

3

Hours/Week (L-T-P)

3+0+0(L+T+P)

 

CIE Marks

50

Total Hrs

39L

 

SEE Marks

50

Exam Hrs

03

 

Course Type

Engg Core

COURSE OUTCOMES

After completion of the course, students will be able to,

1. Describe the origin, and properties of soil and analyze the index properties. (L2)

2. Identify and classify the soil as per specified codal provisions (L3)

3. Evaluate the permeability and shear strength parameters of the soil (L3)

4. Analyze and evaluate the compaction and consolidation properties of soil (L3)

TEACHING METHODOLOGY

●  Blackboard teaching/PowerPoint presentations (if needed)

●  Flipped Classes/through Self learning If required.

●  Laboratory demonstrations

●  Regular review of students by asking questions based on topics covered in the class

COURSE CONTENTS

UNIT -1- (9L+0T+0P)

Introduction: History of soil mechanics, Origin and formation of soil, Definitions,

Phase Diagram, Voids ratio, Porosity, Percentage Air Voids, Air content, Degree of saturation, Water content, Specific Gravity of soil solids and soil mass, Densities and Unit weights - Bulk, Dry, Saturated & Submerged and their inter relationships.

Index properties of soil and their determination:

Index Properties of soil- Water content , Specific  Gravity, Particle size distribution, Relative Density, Consistency limits and indices, in-situ density,  Activity of Clay, Laboratory methods of determination of index properties of soil: Water content (Oven Drying method & Rapid Moisture method), Specific gravity of soil solids (Pycnometer and density bottle method)Particle size distribution (Sieve analysis and Hydrometer analysis only), Liquid Limit- (Casagrande and Cone penetration methods), Plastic limit and shrinkage limit.

UNIT -2- (8L+0T+0P)

Classification of soils: Purpose, Particle size classification – MIT classification, Textural classification, IS classification-Plasticity chart and its importance, Field Identification of soils.  

Clay mineralogy and soil structure: Single grained, honey combed, flocculent and dispersed structures, Valence bonds, Soil-Water system, Electrical diffuse double layer, adsorbed water, base-exchange capacity, Isomorphous substitution. Common clay minerals in soil and their structures.

UNIT -3- (7L+0T+0P)

Flow of water through soils:  Darcy’s law- assumption and validity, coefficient of permeability and its determination (laboratory and field), factors affecting permeability, permeability of stratified soils, Seepage velocity, Superficial velocity and coefficient of percolation, quicksand condition.  

Compaction of soil: Definition, Principle of compaction, Standard and Modified proctor’s compaction tests, factors affecting compaction, effect of compaction on soil properties, **Field compaction control – compactive effort & methods-Proctor’s needle method, Compacting equipment. **

UNIT -4- (8L+0T+0P)

Shear strength of soil: Concept of shear strength, Mohr-coulomb theory, conventional and modified failure envelops, Effective stress concept- total stress, effective stress and Neutral stress,  Concept of pore water pressure, Total and effective shear strength parameters, factors affecting shear strength of soils.

Consolidation of soil: Definition, Mass-spring analogy, Terzaghi’s one dimensional consolidation theory-assumption and limitations (no derivation), Normally consolidated, under consolidated and over consolidated soils, pre-consolidation pressure and its determination by Casagrande’s method. Consolidation characteristics of soil (CC, av, mv and CV)

UNIT -5- (7L+0T+0P)

Determination of shear strength and consolidation of soil: Measurement of shear parameters- ***Direct shear test, unconfined compression test, Triaxial compression test and vane shear test***, Test under different drainage conditions. Determination of consolidation characteristics of soils-compression index and coefficient of consolidation (square root of time fitting method, logarithmic time fitting method, Two-way slab

TEXTBOOKS

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Gopal Ranjan and Rao A.S.R, Basic and Applied Soil Mechanics, (2000), New Age International (P) Ltd., Newe Delhi

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Murthy V.N.S, Principles of Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engineering, (1996), UBS Publishers and Distributors, New Delhi.43

 

 

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

 

Punmia B.C, Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engg, (2005), Laxmi Publications   Co., New Delhi.

REFERENCE BOOKS

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Bowles J.E, Foundation Analysis and Design, (1996), McGraw Hill Pub. Co. New York.

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

Alam Singh and Chowdhary G.R, Soil Engineering in Theory and Practice, (1994), CBS Publishers and Distributors Ltd., New Delhi.

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

 Shashi K. Gulathi & Manoj Datta, Geotechnical Engineering, (2009), “Tata Mc Graw Hill.

UNIT 1,2,3,4,5

 Narasimha Rao A. V. & Venkatrahmaiah C, Numerical Problems, Examples and objective questions in Geotechnical Engineering, (2000), Universities Press., Hyderabad.

Subject: Portions for MSE1 Message:

Introduction to software project management: Introduction, why is software project management important? What is a project? , Software projects versus other types of project, Contract management and technical project management, Activities covered by software project management, Plans, methods and Methodologies, Some ways of categorizing software projects, Stakeholders, Setting objectives, The business case, Project success and failure.  What is management? Management control. Selection of an appropriate project approach: Introduction, Build or buy?, Choosing methodologies and Technologies,  Choice of process models,  Structure versus speed of delivery, Selecting the most appropriate process model. Project Evaluation – A business case, project portfolio management, Evaluation of individual projects, Cost-benefit evaluation techniques.

An overview or project planning (Text 1: Chapter 3) (include Gantt Chart), (Text 1: Chapter 8) Resource allocation: Introduction, The nature of resources, Identifying resource requirements, Software effort estimation (Text 1: Chapter 5): Introduction, Where are estimates done? , Problems with over- and underestimates, the basis for software estimating, Software effort estimation techniques, bottom -up estimating, the top-down approach and parametric models, Expert judgment, estimating by analogy.

Subject: Syllabus Message:

INTRODUCTION TO AIRCRAFT ENGINEERING (21AE32)

COURSE OUTCOMES

Course outcomes: After completion of the course, students will be able to-

1. Describe the history and configurations of aircraft

2. Explain the various types of airfoils and wings

3. Analyse the performance of aircrafts

4. Analyse structural components of aircraft

5. Understand various design parameters of aircrafts


TEACHING METHODOLOGY

 Blackboard teaching/PowerPoint presentation (if needed) /Flipped Classes for specified topics

 Regular review of students by asking questions based on topics covered in the class


COURSE CONTENTS

UNIT-1 - (10 HOURS)

History and Aircraft Configurations

Early development of Airplanes, biplanes and monoplanes, Developments in materials, structures

and propulsion over the years, types of flight vehicles, Classifications-Components of an airplane

and their functions.

Environments: Design Motivation, Atmosphere and its character, pressure measurement, standard

atmosphere, use of standard atmosphere.


UNIT-2 - (10 HOURS)

Aerodynamics, Airfoils and Wings: Design Motivation, Basic aerodynamics, Aerodynamics

Application, Viscous flow, airfoil characteristics , wings, High lift device, Aircraft lift, Aircraft

Drag and Drag polar, Mach number effect, Aircraft analysis example.


UNIT-3 - (10 HOURS)

Performance: Design Motivation, equation of motion, propulsion, drag curve, lift to drag ratio,

power curves, curve shifts, glides, cline range and endurance, take off and landing, turns, V-

notation energy height and specific excess power.


UNIT-4 - (10 HOURS)

Structures and Sizing: Design Motivation, Types of stress, loads, structural layout, materials,

component sizing, structural sizing examples, weight estimates, FEA, Internal layout, structural

weight, geometry constraints, mission analysis, sizing equations, weight fraction method, weight

and balance mission analysis and sizing examples, aerodynamics cost.


UNIT-5 - (08 HOURS)

Design: Introduction, design method, example, Brief history of aircraft design, conceptual design

introduction, 12 activities, custom faces, design synthesis, geometry modeling and engineering

drawing, Aerodynamic analysis, Constraint analysis, Mission analysis, weight analysis sizing, cost

analysis, optimization, performance case study(F-16).

Subject: Assignment 5 Message:

Complete the assignment and upload 

1. State Sampling Theorem. 

2. Define aliasing and illustrate the corrective measures to combat the effect of aliasing. 

3. Illustrate PAM with neat waveform and two operations involved in the generation of PAM. 

4. Explain basic elements of Pulse Code Modulation (PCM) system with a block diagram. 

5. Illustrate two different forms of pulse time modulation with a sinusoidal modulating wave. 

 6. Infer Differential Encoding with an example binary data 

7. Given the data stream 1110010100, sketch the transmitted sequence of pulses for each of the following Line codes: i) Unipolar nonreturn to zero ii) Polar nonreturn to zero iii) Unipolar return to zero iv) Bipolar return to zero v) Manchester code 

8. Explain the function of the Regenerative Repeater with a block diagram.

Subject: Questions (preparation for MSE3) Message:


1.  Truth Tables  OR, AND, Implies, Equivalence (Read notes on Propositional Calculus)

    you are also encouraged to read  from chapter 7 - Figure 7.1, Section 7.1, Figure 7.2 and associated text,  P: Precondition List A: Add List D:Delete List; Definition we say that a state satisfies a goal... Section 7.2, Figure 7.4, Section 7.3   )

4. Forward State Space Planning and Backward State Space Planning (Read Notes on Planning) (Read also Deepak Khemani's book, some relevant sections already mentioned above, Figure 7.5 Read about Progress and Regress functions; S, S1 states g, g'  states and so on, Figure 7.6 Definition of a Planning problem)

6.. Solution for Prisoner's dilemma (Read PPT Notes on Gaming; You are also encouraged to read Prisoner's dilemma from Deepak Khemani's book available in Game Playing chapter)

7.  Gaming Trees and Algorithm covered (Read Notes PPT on Game Playing; You are also encouraged to read Board Games 8.1 from text book(Khemani), 8.1.1 Game Trees - MiniMax Rule, understand Figure 8.5; Figure 8.7 and the rest

Note:
For MSE3 , it is mandatory to first read given notes on Game Playing , Propositional Calculus, Predicate Calculus, Planning.  It is desirable if you can read text book sections from chapters mentioned above for MSE3, however, it is mandatory for SEE.

Subject: Open Book Test Message:

Open Book Test Questions

 

Set 1

 

1.      Write a short note on THE DESIGN CYCLE                 

2.      Analyse Linear Basis Function

3.      Analyse Geometry of least squares                                    

4.      Analyse Multiple outputs                                                   

5.      Write a short note on Choosing the Target Function      

                                 

Set 2

 

1.      Write a short note on Segmentation and Grouping     

2.      Analyse the Bias-Variance Decomposition

3.      Analyse Regularized least squares

4.      Analyse Predictive distribution

5.      Write a short note on The Final Design

Subject: Questions for Slow Learners Message:

Answer the following:

1. Consider a fish packing plant wants to automate the process of sorting incoming fish on a conveyor belt according to species. Illustrate the steps to be followed for classification.

2. How does this Bias-Variance decomposition work.

3. What do you mean by well posed learning problem? With an example, state the task, performance measure and training experience.

4. Given the Checkers learning problem paraphrase on the design cycle for the analysis of the game.

5. A lab test is 95% effective in detecting a disease. It has a false rate of 1%. Rate of occurrence of the disease is 0.5%. If a person takes a test and get a positive result, What is the likelihood that he has disease?

6. Discuss the problem of underfitting in a model along with an example?

7. Derive an expression for Maximum likelihood & least squares.

8. Fit a Linear Regression curve by following the Least Square estimation of the following points and estimate the Goodness of fit. (-3,0), (-1,1), (0,2), (2,3).

9. Brief a short note on any two Pattern Recognition Approaches.

Subject: CNS UNIT_2 ASSIGNMENTS Message:

1.      Demonstrate symmetric cipher model with a neat diagram.

2.      Explain Ceasar cipher algorithm’s  working with an example.

3.       With the given  data encrypt the plain text using hill cipher method.

 Input : Plaintext: ACT,  Key: GNBNQKURP,  Ciphertext: POH

Subject: Course Outcomes Message:

Students will be able to
1. Understand the relationship between energy, environment, and sustainable development
with respect to Global & Indian context.
2. Articulate the Energy Consumption Rates, Importance of agriculture and impact of
population growth and environmental degradation.
3. Identify the effects of pollutants on air & water and compare with its quality standards.
4. Infer policies and India’s legal framework towards energy, environment, and sustainability.
5. Analyze the functional elements of municipal waste, biomedical waste, Industrial waste, E-wastes
and their policies for sustainable development

Subject: Case Study/Survey/Project Message:

You have been given the responsibility of choosing the topics for the Learning Activity components. This task requires careful consideration and research to ensure that the topics are relevant, interesting, and aligned with the Energy Environment and Sustainability wrt Local region.

Once you have selected the topics, you are required to prepare a comprehensive report that outlines the learning activities for each topic. The report should include details such as the objectives, learning outcomes, materials, and resources required for each activity.

In addition to the report, you are also required to create a 5-minute video about the project. The video should provide an overview of the learning activities, explain the objectives and expected outcomes, and highlight the resources and materials required.

To ensure that the project is completed on time, you should start working on the report and video as soon as possible. You should also make sure to follow the guidelines and requirements provided by your instructor or supervisor.

Finally, it is important to remember that the quality of your report and video will have a significant impact on your grade or evaluation. Therefore, you should take the time to review and revise your work before submitting it through the Learning Management System (LMS) by the deadline of May 21st 2023.

Subject: Earth Day Message:

Dear Students,

 As we celebrate Earth Day today, it is important to reflect on the significance of this day. Earth Day is a global event that aims to raise awareness about the importance of protecting our planet and preserving its natural resources. It reminds us of the urgent need to take action to combat climate change, reduce pollution, and promote sustainable living practices.

 On this Earth Day, I urge you all to make a pledge towards a pollution-free and sustainable green environment. Let us make a commitment to reduce our carbon footprint, conserve water and energy, and recycle our waste. By taking small but meaningful actions, we can collectively make a significant impact on our planet and ensure a better future for generations to come.

 To aid in your learning activities (Survey/Case study/Project), I have shared some books that I downloaded from https://www.earthday.org/india/, which I found to be very informative and useful through LMS. These resources provide valuable insights on environmental issues, and I believe that they can help you in executing your LA. I encourage you to make the most of these resources and learn more about how we can protect our planet and promote sustainability.

 Let us all work together to make a positive difference on this Earth Day and beyond.

 Regards

Dr Kiran Aithal S

Subject: Attendance Message:

Dear Students,

I am writing to you today to address the issue of students not attending classes and the consequences that follow. It is essential for all students to attend their classes regularly to achieve academic success and progress. However, it has come to our notice that some of you have not been attending your classes regularly, and this is a matter of concern.

As you are aware, regular attendance is a fundamental requirement for academic success. Attending classes regularly ensures that you are up to date with the course material and enables you to participate in classroom discussions, which can significantly impact your grades. It is important to note that when you do not attend classes, you are not only missing out on valuable learning opportunities, but you are also putting your academic progress at risk.

Furthermore, I must emphasize that not attending classes has consequences that go beyond academic performance. Students who miss classes are also missing out on developing critical skills such as time management, discipline, and responsibility. These skills are essential for success in any field, and not developing them can affect your future prospects.

 As a result of your absence from classes, you will not be eligible to appear for the upcoming Semester End Examinations. It is crucial to understand that attending classes is a prerequisite for taking examinations, and without meeting this requirement, you cannot appear for the exams. We understand that there may be reasons why you were not able to attend classes. Still, it is your responsibility to ensure that you attend classes regularly and make up for any missed coursework.

 In conclusion, I urge all students to take their attendance seriously and attend classes regularly. Doing so will not only help you achieve academic success but also develop critical skills necessary for success in life. I hope you understand the importance of attendance and take the necessary steps to ensure that you do not miss any more classes.

 Best regards,

Dr Kiran Aithal S

Subject: LA2 -Case study Message:

Dear Students,

 

As a part of the course curriculum and learning activity evaluation students should form a team of 3(Mandatory), Choose a Paper under the domain of Big Data Analytics and the same is to be presented along with report.

Note:  Refer Scopus/web of science/IEEE/Taylor publication etc. 2019 onward technical papers only.

 

The deadline for submitting topic along with the team is 6th  May 2023

 

Guidelines for the presentation:

 

1. Each Team submit PowerPoint presentation based on the paper submitted. It must be an individual effort, though discussions with team mates are allowed.

 

2. The PowerPoint is supposed to be a summary of the paper. So your presentation should cover the following points in a small number of slides:

 

- Title slide which should have the Title and your name.

- Overview of the paper. Explanation of the topic/problem you are covering and why it is important. 

- Explain details of the topic, including issues and challenges.

- Explain how the issues or challenges are addressed.

- Conclusion

 

ps - Include figures if they help explain the concepts.

 

3. Student Groups should present the topic in the class. Presentation not more than 15 min per team.

 

Criteria for evaluation

-Paper selection (3).

-Team work & Presentation quality (4).

-Report Submission (3)

 

 

Report should consist of the following

1. Introduction

2. Problem Statement

3. Implementation details

4. Challenges and issues

5. Conclusion

6. Copy of the base paper

7. References

 

 

The Schedule for the presentation will be shared on 11th  May 2023.

Subject: Report Format_to be submitted on 23rd May Message:

Dear Students,

Please find attached the format to be followed while writing your report. It is important to adhere to this format as any deviations may result in the rejection of your report.

Format for Report:

  1. Title Page: Include the title of your report, the name of your team, and the date of submission.

  2. Table of Contents: Provide a clear and organized list of the sections and subsections in your report along with their corresponding page numbers.

  3. Introduction: Give a brief overview of the Learning Activity (LA) and its objectives. Explain why this LA is important and how it relates to the course or subject.

  4. Methodology: Describe the approach or methods used to carry out the LA. Include details of any research, experiments, or data collection techniques employed.

  5. Results and Analysis: Present your findings and data collected during the LA. Use tables, graphs, or charts to present your information effectively. Analyze the results and draw conclusions based on your observations.

  6. Discussion: Discuss the significance of your findings and their implications. Compare your results with established theories or previous research in the field. Address any limitations or challenges encountered during the LA.

  7. Conclusion: Summarize the key points of your report and reiterate the main findings. Highlight the overall success of the LA and its contribution to your learning experience.

  8. References: Cite all the sources used in your report, including books, research papers, websites, or any other references consulted during the LA.

Please note that the format provided above is specific to the written report. However, for your PPT and video, you have the freedom to be creative and design them in your own unique way. There are no specific formats for the PPT and video.

For the PPT:

  • Ensure that the content is clear, concise, and visually appealing.
  • Use appropriate headings, bullet points, and visuals to convey your information effectively.
  • Maintain a logical flow of ideas and include relevant images or graphs to support your points.
  • Make sure the text is legible and not overloaded with information.

For the video:

  • Prepare a 5-minute video where your team explains the work carried out for the LA.
  • Clearly present the objectives, methodology, and findings of your LA.
  • Engage the audience through effective communication, enthusiasm, and clarity.
  • Use visuals, props, or demonstrations to enhance the presentation.
  • Rehearse the video beforehand to ensure a smooth and coherent delivery.

Remember, the focus of both the PPT and video should be on effectively communicating your work and findings. Use your team's creativity to make them engaging and informative.

Best of luck with your report and presentation!

Dr Kiran Aithal S

Subject: Syllabus Message:

Module-1: Probability and Random Variables                       (8 hours)

Probability: Definition, sum and product Rule, Conditional Probability.

Random variable -: Probability distribution- discrete and continuous, probability density function, cumulative density function, mean and variance, expectation.

Joint distribution - discrete and continuous, marginal distribution, expectation, covariance.

Module-2: Probability Distributions and Sampling                       (8 hours)

Probability Distribution: Binomial, Poisson, Normal distribution, exponential distribution, uniform distribution.

Theory of Sampling: Population and sample, sampling with and without replacement, sampling distribution of means and variance, confidence intervals for mean.

                                              Module - 3:Sampling                                                                                 (8 hours)

Testing Hypothesis, one tailed and two tailed test, testing of large samples, significance level, testing small samples using  t – test,test for goodness of fit, F-test and Analysis of variance for one factor experiments.

Module-4: Correlation and Regression                                        (8 hours)

Correlation, Karl Pearson’s coefficient of correlation, Rank correlation, Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient, Regression lines, multiple regression. 

Mathematical models for time series: Graphical curve fitting, least square curve fitting,

  Angle between regression lines, relation between correlation coefficient and lines of regression.

Module - 5: Linear Algebra                                          (8 hours)

Vector spaces- Introduction, subspaces, Linear combinations, linear dependence, basis and dimension, linear Transformation, matrix representation of linear transformation, , inner products, orthogonal vectors, Gram Schmidt Orthogonalization process

Subject: Syllabus Message:

Module-1: Solution of Ordinary Differential Equations            (8 hours)

Linear and Bernoulli’s differential equations, Exact differential equation,

Complementary function and Particular Integral for higher order linear differential equations with constant coefficients, Variation of Parameters
Applications:   LCR circuits, Charging and discharging capacitor

Self study:  Undetermined coefficients

Module-2:    Numerical Methods-I            (8 hours)

Solution of algebraic and transcendental equations: Regula – Falsi method, Newton Raphson method Finite differences, Interpolation: Newton Forward, Backward , Lagrange Interpolation
Curve Fitting:  Fitting curves using least square method, straight line, parabolic and exponential curves.

Self-Study: Bisection method, Derivatives using Newton’s formulae.

 

     Module - 3:  Numerical methods - 2             (8 hours)

Solving system of equations by Gauss- Siedel Method, LU decomposition method, Thomas algorithm, Eigenvalues of symmetric matrices using Jacobi and Given’s Method.

Applications: Solving linear systems generated from electrical circuits.

Self-Study: Errors in numerical Methods, round off error, chopping error, relative error, truncation error.

Module-4: Linear Algebra                                       (8 hours)

Vector spaces- definition, examples, Linear combinations, sub spaces, linear dependence, basis and dimension, linear mapping, linear operator, Kernel and Image of a Linear mapping, matrix representation of linear operator, change of basis., Applications

Self Study:  Row Space and Column space, Rank and nullity theorem

Module - 5: Linear Algebra                                    (8 hours)

Inner product space, Orthogonal Sets and Bases, Gram Schmidt Orthogonalization process, Polynomial of matrices, Characteristic polynomial, Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors, diagonalization, Characteristic and minimal polynomial. Applications.

Self-Study: Block matrices and Canonical form.

Subject: Regarding the internal lab test Message:

Dear Students

As informed in the last class, an internal test is scheduled on 27th at 1.45 pm in the lab. Follow the instructions below for the test:

- The test is for 90 minutes

- Questions will be available in LMS (total 10 questions) during the test.

- You need to solve the questions using MATLAB commands using LAB PC only. (using desktop editor)

- After executing the results, copy and paste the commands and the results from your MATLAB editor.

- At the end of the test, you need to save your complete workspace as .mat file (in local system) and upload in a separate submission link. This will be verified to ensure you do not indulge in malpractice.

- No mobile phones, laptops or electronic gadgets to be used. You need to have only two windows opened at any time during the test. One is MATLAB desktop and the LMS in browser. No other tabs or windows are allowed. In case you are found to use any other tabs, IT WILL BE TREATED AS MALPRACTICE AND YOU WILL BE AWARDED ZERO.

- Please remember, this mark will be playing a major role in your CIE.

- Attempt the test honestly. All the best

Dr Mohan S G

7.      Discuss on Selective Repeat Request Protocol with a suitable diagram.

8.      Explain Go-back-n protocol with suitable diagram.

Subject: Note on Number of Threads in OpenMP Message:

Dear all,

During the lab test we observed that most of the students have mentioned number of threads in OpenMP program , as the same number of input or the data. This will lead to poor programming.

The thread parallelism is to improve performance. There should be ideal number that need to be considered to get the better performance. 

Note that whatever number of threads created , how many cores are there in the system, so many threads only will execute in parallel. If I have 30 threads ,  4 cores , there will be 8 cycles of threads will be executed. If 2 cores are there 15 cycles are executed.

Subject: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

Justify your opinion on the Electronic Code Book Vs Cipher Block Chanining  in terms of security

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

The main difference between ECB and CBC is that ECB encrypts each and every block independently but CBC encrypts the blocks based on the previous block.So CBC is more resistance to pattern recognition attacks than ECB and i think CBC is more secure than ECB.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

The major difference between ECB vs CBC is that ECB encryptes each block independently.where as CBC encryptes each block  with previous block.

Cryptography methods such as Electronic Code book ECB and Cipher Block Chaining CBC are widely used.

ECB and CBC are symmetric-key encryption methods, meaning that the same key is used for encryption and decryption. As computing power increases, it becomes increasingly important to use more secure encryption methods.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:
ECB encrypts each block independently, whereas CBC encrypts each block with the previous block.
ECB is less secure, as identical plaintext blocks are encrypted into identical ciphertext blocks. CBC introduces a feedback mechanism where each ciphertext block depends on all previous blocks, adding an extra layer of security by disrupting patterns.
So,CBC is more secure that ECB

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

ECB mode encrypts each block of data independently, without using any of the previous blocks. This means that if the same block of data appears multiple times in the message, it will be encrypted to the same ciphertext each time. This can make it easier for an attacker to decrypt the message, as they can exploit any patterns in the plaintext.

CBC mode encrypts each block of data using the ciphertext of the previous block. This means that each block of ciphertext is dependent on the previous block, which makes it more difficult for an attacker to decrypt the message.

Security:ECB is less secured as compared to CBC

Performance: ECB mode is faster than CBC mode

Padding: Padding is required for ECB mode whereas CBC doesn't requires padding

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

CBC (Cipher Block Chaining):


Strengths: Less vulnerable to certain attacks compared to ECB.

Operation: XORs each plaintext block with the previous ciphertext block before encryption, which adds diffusion.

Security: Resistant to identical plaintext blocks generating identical ciphertext blocks, providing some level of confidentiality.

Weaknesses: Susceptible to certain types of attacks like padding oracle attacks and manipulation of initialisation vectors (IVs).



ECB (Electronic Codebook):


Weaknesses: More vulnerable than CBC.

Operation: Encrypts each plaintext block separately, which can result in identical plaintext blocks producing identical ciphertext blocks.

Security: Prone to revealing patterns in the plaintext, which can compromise confidentiality, especially for repetitive data.

Use Cases: Less secure for encrypting multiple blocks of data with the same key due to its deterministic nature.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

In Electronic Code Book, each block of plain text is subjected to the encryption process one at a time, separately producing the encrypted data. It can do parallel encryption of blocks.

In Cipher Block Chaining, every plain text block is XORed with the preceding encrypted block. It needs previous Cipher block for generating the output.

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:

Symmetric cryptography uses a single key for both encryption and decryption, where both parties involved share the same secret key. It's efficient for large amounts of data but requires secure key exchange. Asymmetric cryptography, on the other hand, uses a pair of public and private keys. Messages encrypted with the public key can only be decrypted with the corresponding private key, providing secure communication without a need for a shared secret.




Symmetric cryptography is faster but faces key distribution challenges, while asymmetric cryptography offers better key management and secure communication but is computationally more intensive. Often, a hybrid approach is used, combining the strengths of both systems for a more secure an

Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:

Block ciphers are encryption methods that process fixed-size blocks of data using a secret key. Here are some examples:


AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Widely used and secure, it comes in key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits.


DES (Data Encryption Standard): An older standard with a 56-bit key, now considered insecure.


Triple DES (3DES): A more secure variant of DES, using three 56-bit keys.


Blowfish: Known for its speed and flexibility, with a variable key size.


Twofish: Developed as a secure and versatile alternative to DES, with key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits.


These block ciphers are crucial for securing data in various applications. The choice depends on factors like security needs and performance requirements.

Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:

A block cipher is an encryption method that applies a deterministic algorithm along with symmetric key to encrypt a block of text , rather than encrypting one bit at a time as in stream ciphers.

Example: common block cipher,AES encrypts 128 bit block with a key of predetermined length: 128,192,or 156 bits

Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:
A block cipher is a method of encrypting data in blocks to produce ciphertext using a cryptographic key and algorithm.
For example :
Twofish is a symmetric key block cipher with a block size of 128 bits and key sizes up to 256 bits. It was one of the five finalists of the Advanced Encryption Standard contest, but it was not selected for standardization.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

INTRODUCTION

Both Electronic Code Book and Cipher Block Chaining are algorithms which is used to encrypt one block of text at a time.This is called Block Cipher.


ECB VS CBC

The Electronic Code Book is a very basic encryption algorithm which is mainly used for encrypting small messages.

The Cipher Block Chaining is advanced form of Block Cipher which is suitable to encrypt large text messages.

IN TERMS OF SECURITY

Ecb

The Electronic Code Book is not secure than the Cipher Block Chaining.

It is because the ECB algorithm encrypts a plain text by converting it into a sub-block and then into a Cipher text using a key.This method results in producing the same Cipher text for two plain texts if the plain texts are the same.The decrypting process is simple when the same key is used to decrypt the sub-block into plain text and combining them finally to get the message.


Cbc

CBC is very much secure than the Ecb.

This is because the Cipher Block Chaining algorithm first divides the messages into sub-blocks of 64 bits and then uses an Initialization Vector(IV) along with the first sub-block and a key for encryption.The next encryption is done using the sub-block and previous Cipher text produced.This results in a more secure encryption.The decryption is done using the same process but uses IV for every decryption of sub-block.


Therefore in terms of security CBC gains advantage over ECB.

Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:

Block ciphers are cryptographic algorithms that operate on fixed-size blocks of data, converting plaintext blocks into ciphertext blocks. They use a symmetric key, meaning the same key is used for both encryption and decryption.

1.AES(Advanced Encryption Standard):One of the most widely used block ciphers. It supports key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits and operates on 128-bit blocks. AES has become the standard encryption algorithm for secure data transmission.

2.DES (Data Encryption Standard): Although outdated for modern security standards, DES was one of the earliest block ciphers. It operates on 64-bit blocks with a 56-bit key. Due to its vulnerability to brute-force attacks, it has been largely replaced by AES.

In my opinion cbc(cipher block chaining) is better as in ecb electronic code book in case of same plain text the cipher text will also be the same whereas in cbc there is a concept of chaining meaning the blocks arent independent as seen in ecb here the repeating pattrns of bits arent exposed as the same plain text will have a different cipher text

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:

Encryption is a process to change the form of any message in order to protect it from reading by anyone.

In Symmetric-key encryption the message is encrypted by using a key and the same key is used to decrypt the message. It is much easier and fast during the transfer as it uses only an single key for both the encryption and decryption.

In asymmetric key encryption it uses two different key to encrypt and decrypt the message.first one is public key which is used during the encryption of message and the other one is private key which is used during the decryption of message

Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:
A block cipher is a symmetric key cryptographic algorithm that operates on fixed-size blocks of data. It transforms plaintext blocks into ciphertext blocks using a key, and the same key is used for both encryption and decryption.
Block ciphers process data in fixed-size blocks. Common block sizes include 64, 128, or 256 bits.
The security of a block cipher is often closely tied to the size of its key. Longer keys generally provide greater security.
Block ciphers are often used in conjunction with modes of operation to process data larger than the block size. Common modes include ECB(Electronic Code Book), CBC (Cipher Block Chaining), and OFB (Output Feedback).

Examples of Block Ciphers:
1. AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Widely adopted and considered highly secure. Used in various applications, including encryption of sensitive data.
2. DES (Data Encryption Standard): One of the earliest standardized block ciphers. Now considered insecure due to its short key length.

3. Triple DES (3DES): Applies the DES algorithm three times to each data block, enhancing security. Used in legacy systems.

4. Blowfish: Designed for efficient software implementation. While still considered secure, it has been largely replaced by newer algorithms.

5. IDEA (International Data Encryption Algorithm): Developed as a strong, efficient algorithm. While widely used in the past, it is less common today.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:



Electronic Codebook (ECB):

- Pros: Simple and can be processed in parallel.

- Cons: Repetitive patterns in plaintext can be visible, and it's vulnerable to tampering.


Cipher Block Chaining (CBC):

- *Pros:* Offers better security by spreading the influence of one block across others, making tampering more detectable.

- *Cons:* Sequential processing and requires careful management of an Initialization Vector (IV).


**Justification:**

- **Security:** CBC is generally more secure due to its ability to hide patterns and resist tampering.

- **Tamper Resistance:** CBC is better at detecting unauthorized changes in the data.

- **Pattern Hiding:** CBC helps in hiding patterns, making it more suitable for secure applications. 


In summary, while ECB is simpler, CBC is often preferred for its enhanced security features, especially when pattern recognition or tamper resistance is important.

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:

Symmetric cryptography:

1.uses a single key to encrypt and decrypt data.

2.faster encryption process.

3.cipher text is smaller or same size as original plain text.

4.can handle large amounts of data.

Assymetric cryptography:

1.uses public key to encrypt data and private key to decrypt data.

2.slower encryption process.

3.cipher text is larger or same size as the original cipher text.

4.can handle small amounts of data.

Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:

A block cipher is a cryptographic algorithm that encrypts fixed-size blocks of plaintext into ciphertext. It operates on fixed-length groups of bits, transforming them into encrypted blocks of the same length.

Example : With The Help Of AES ......

Plaintext: 0011010101111000 (16 bits)


Key: 1011100100110101 (16 bits)

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:
Symmetric Cryptography :

Key Type: Uses a single, shared secret key for both encryption and decryption.

Speed: Generally faster than asymmetric cryptography since the algorithms are less complex.

Scalability: Can face challenges when it comes to key distribution, especially in large networks, as every pair of communicating parties needs a unique key.

Examples: DES, AES.

Asymmetric Cryptography:

Key Type: Involves a pair of keys – a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption. The keys are mathematically related but cannot be derived from each other easily.

Speed: Slower compared to symmetric cryptography due to the complexity of the algorithms.

Scalability: Solves the key distribution problem as each entity has a public-private key pair. The public keys can be freely distributed, and private keys are kept secret.

Examples: RSA, ECC (Elliptic Curve Cryptography).

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:
ECB is used for transmitting a single value whereas CBC mode is used for a block of text authentication.
In ECB, each block of ciphertext that is encrypted is independent of other cipher blocks, whereas in CBC each block of ciphertext is dependent on the corresponding current input plain text as well as a previous plain text block.
Electronic code block does use a feedback mechanism whereas Cipher Block Chaining uses a feedback mechanism.
If a plain text block is repeated in the original message, Electronic Code Book mode generates the same ciphertext block for each corresponding plain text block, whereas Cipher Block Chaining mode generates different ciphertext blocks for each corresponding plain text block.
ECB mode is used for encrypting small messages as the chances of decoding the ciphertext are higher. In contrast, CBC mode is used for encrypting large messages as the chances of decoding the ciphertext are much lower.

ECB does not make use of the feedback mechanism. In CBC, each block of ciphertext is independent of other blocks. ECB does not perform XOR operation. 

Cbc-CBC stands for Cipher Block Chaining. It is used for encrypting blocks of text authentication.It is suitable for encrypting the large messages. In CBC, it is quite difficult for the attacker to decode the ciphertext.if the block of plain text is repeated in the original message, CBC will generate different ciphertext blocks for the repeated block. Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:
Symmetric Cryptography:

Single Key: Symmetric cryptography uses a single secret key for both encryption and decryption. The same key is shared between the communicating parties.

Faster: Symmetric algorithms are generally faster and computationally more efficient than asymmetric algorithms. They are well-suited for bulk data encryption.

Challenging: The major challenge lies in securely distributing the secret key to all parties involved without interception, especially in large networks.

Examples:
AES (Advanced Encryption Standard), DES (Data Encryption Standard), 3DES (Triple DES): Common symmetric encryption algorithms.

Asymmetric Cryptography:

Key Pair: Asymmetric cryptography uses a pair of keys – public and private. The public key is used for encryption, while the private key is used for decryption.

Slower: Asymmetric algorithms are computationally more intensive than symmetric ones. They are often used for key exchange and digital signatures rather than bulk data encryption.

Simpler: Public keys can be freely distributed, solving the key distribution challenge present in symmetric cryptography. Private keys must be kept confidential.

Examples:

RSA (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman), ECC (Elliptic Curve Cryptography), DSA (Digital Signature Algorithm): Common asymmetric encryption and signature algorithms.

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:
Symmetric Cryptography:

  1. Uses a single shared secret key for both encryption and decryption. This means both parties involved need to have and keep the same secret key.
  2. One key is used for both encryption and decryption.
  3. Requires a secure way to distribute the shared secret key to all parties involved without it being intercepted.
  4. Generally faster and computationally less complex than asymmetric cryptography.
  5. Often used for encrypting large amounts of data efficiently, such as in bulk data transfer

Whereas,


Asymmetric Cryptography:


  1. Involves a pair of keys - a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption. The public key can be shared openly, but the private key must be kept secret.
  2. Two keys (a key pair) are used, with each key having a specific role in the process.
  3. Public keys can be freely distributed, while private keys must be kept confidential. This simplifies key distribution as the public key can be openly shared.
  4. More computationally intensive due to the use of key pairs and mathematical algorithms.
  5. Commonly used for tasks like secure key exchange, digital signatures, and establishing secure communication channels.

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:

Asymmetric Cryptographic:- It uses the different key for both data encryption and data decryption. It uses public and private keys in order to encrypt and decrypt data respectively.It is little slower in terms of data transfering.

In this encryption technique, the message is encrypted with a key, and the same key is used for decrypting the message. It is the simplest and commonly known encryption technique. It makes it easy to use but less secure.
Asymmetric encryption uses two keys for encryption and decryption. It is based on the technique of public and private keys. A public key, which is interchanged between more than one user. Data is decrypted by a private key, which is not exchanged. It is slower but more secure. The public key used in this encryption technique is available to everyone, but the private key used in it is not disclosed.

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:

Symmetric cryptography uses a single, shared key for both encryption and decryption. It's efficient for large amounts of data but requires a secure method for key exchange. Asymmetric cryptography, on the other hand, involves a pair of keys: public and private. Data encrypted with one key can only be decrypted with the other. While it provides a more secure key exchange, it is computationally more intensive, often used for securing key exchange in symmetric systems.symmetric cryptography is faster but requires secure key exchange, while asymmetric cryptography offers a more secure key exchange but is computationally more demanding. Hybrid systems, combining both methods, are often used for a balance of speed and security in various applications.

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:

Key Types:

Symmetric Cryptography: Uses a single, shared key for both encryption and decryption.

Asymmetric Cryptography: Utilizes a pair of keys – public and private. The public key encrypts, and the private key decrypts.


Key Distribution:

Symmetric Cryptography: Requires secure key distribution as both parties need the same key.

Asymmetric Cryptography: Public keys can be distributed openly, while private keys remain secret.


Speed:

Symmetric Cryptography: Generally faster due to simpler algorithms, making it more efficient for bulk data encryption.

Asymmetric Cryptography: Slower due to complex mathematical operations, primarily used for exchanging keys or securing communications in a limited capacity.


Use Cases:

Symmetric Cryptography: Ideal for securing data transmission, especially large volumes of data.

Asymmetric Cryptography: Primarily used for secure key exchange, digital signatures, and establishing secure channels.


Computational Complexity:

Symmetric Cryptography: Less computationally intensive, making it faster and more efficient for encryption/decryption.

Asymmetric Cryptography: More computationally complex due to the involved mathematical operations, leading to slower processing times.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:
Electronic Code Book (ECB):
Strengths:
Simplicity: ECB is straightforward, processing each block independently. This simplicity can be advantageous for certain applications.
Parallelization: Each block can be encrypted or decrypted independently, allowing for parallel processing, which can be beneficial in specific scenarios.
Weaknesses:
Deterministic: Identical blocks of plaintext result in the same ciphertext, which can lead to patterns in the encrypted data.
Lack of Diffusion: Changes in one block don't affect others, making it susceptible to certain attacks, especially when the same plaintext blocks are repeated.

Cipher Block Chaining (CBC):
Strengths:
Diffusion: CBC addresses the lack of diffusion in ECB. Each block's ciphertext is dependent on the previous block, introducing diffusion of information.
Random Initialization Vector (IV): CBC uses a random IV for the first block, adding an extra layer of security and preventing patterns in ciphertext.
Weaknesses:
Sequential Processing: CBC requires sequential processing since each block's encryption depends on the previous block's ciphertext. This can limit parallelization.
Error Propagation: If an error occurs in one block, it affects the decryption of subsequent blocks, potentially leading to data integrity issues.

2.It is used when a large amount of data is required to transfer.

4.It only provides confidentiality.

5. The length of key used is 128 or 256 bits

Asymmetric Key Encryption

1. It requires two keys, a public key and a private key, one to encrypt and the other one to decrypt.

2.It is used to transfer small amounts of data.

3.The size of cipher text is the same or larger than the original plain text.

4.  It provides confidentiality, authenticity, and non-repudiation.

5.The length of key used is 2048 or higher

Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:

Block ciphers are cryptographic algorithms that operate on fixed-size blocks of data, encrypting or decrypting them one block at a time. Each block typically consists of a fixed number of bits, such as 64 or 128. Here are two well-known block ciphers:


AES (Advanced Encryption Standard):


Key Size: AES supports key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits.

Block Size: The block size is fixed at 128 bits.

Operation: AES performs a series of transformations (SubBytes, ShiftRows, MixColumns, AddRoundKey) in multiple rounds based on the key size.

DES (Data Encryption Standard):


Key Size: DES has a fixed key size of 56 bits (with 8 parity bits).

Block Size: The block size is 64 bits.

Operation: DES uses a Feistel network structure with 16 rounds. Each round involves permutation and substitution operations.

Triple DES (3DES):


Key Size: 3DES can use either two or three keys of 56 bits each, resulting in key sizes of 112 or 168 bits.

Block Size: Like DES, the block size is 64 bits.

Operation: 3DES applies the DES algorithm three times (encrypt-decrypt-encrypt) using the specified keys.

Blowfish:


Key Size: Blowfish supports variable key sizes from 32 to 448 bits.

Block Size: The block size is 64 bits.

Operation: Blowfish uses a Feistel network structure with a variable number of rounds. It's known for its simplicity and efficiency.

Twofish:


Key Size: Twofish supports key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits.

Block Size: The block size is 128 bits.

Operation: Twofish employs a Feistel network with a fixed number of 16 rounds. It was a finalist in the AES competition.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:


Electronic Code Book (ECB) and Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) are ways to turn messages into secret code, and they work on one piece of the message at a time. This is known as Block Cipher.


ECB vs CBC:

ECB is a basic method good for small messages, while CBC is a more advanced way suitable for encrypting larger messages.


ECB:

ECB isn't as secure as CBC. It turns a message into code by breaking it into parts and using a key. The problem is, if you have the same message, you get the same code. So, if you know the code for one message, you can figure out others easily.


CBC:

CBC is more secure. It breaks the message into small parts and uses an Initial Vector (IV) along with the first part and a key to make the code. Then, it uses the last code made in the next part of the message. This makes it much harder to figure out the original message just by looking at the codes.


So, when it comes to security, CBC is better than ECB because it's like putting an extra layer of protection on your secret messages.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

CBC is generally considered safer than ECB because it has diffusion properties and is resistant to some attacks. However, CBC’s security is dependent on proper implementation and proper handling of initialization vectors.ECB’s lack of pattern preservation makes it less secure, particularly when encrypting large volumes of data with repeating patterns.When choosing between CBC and ECB, it’s important to consider the security requirements and vulnerabilities of the application system being encrypted. Many current encryption standards and practices prioritize CBC or more sophisticated modes such as galois counter mode.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

Electronic Code Book (ECB) mode and Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) mode are both block cipher modes used in encryption.

In terms of security, ECB is simpler but less secure than CBC. ECB encrypts each block of data independently, which means identical blocks of plaintext will produce identical ciphertext. This lack of diffusion can lead to patterns being visible in the encrypted data.

On the other hand, CBC addresses this issue by XORing each plaintext block with the previous ciphertext block before encryption. This introduces a level of diffusion, making it more resistant to certain attacks compared to ECB.
