Subject: Re: Discuss on block ciphers with examples Message:


A block cipher is like a secret code machine that takes a chunk (block) of your message and turns it into a secret code. It works on fixed-size blocks of data at a time.


Working:

Imagine you have a message, and you cut it into blocks (like paragraphs in a book). The block cipher then takes each block and scrambles it using a secret key, creating a secret code.


Example:

Let's say your message is "HELLO" and the block size is 2 letters. The first block is "HE" and the block cipher, using a secret key, might turn it into "YX." The second block, "LL," could become "AB." So, "HELLO" becomes "YXAB" in secret code.


Security:

The strength of the secret code depends on the key. If someone doesn't know the key, it's hard for them to unscramble the message. But if they have the key, they can easily decode it.


In summary, block ciphers are like secret codes for your messages. They take chunks of your message, scramble them with a key, and create a secret code that's hard to crack without the right key.

Subject: Re: Discuss on the difference between Symmetric and Asymmetric Cryptography Message:

Symmetric cryptography has advantages in terms of speed and efficiency, but it has disadvantages in terms of key distribution. On the other hand, asymmetric cryptography offers better security and allows for secure key exchange, but it tends to be slower than symmetric cryptography. Asymmetric and symmetric encryption are often used interchangeably in modern cryptography, which is known as hybrid cryptography.

A few popular block ciphers are Data Encryption Standard (DES), Blowfish, and Twofish.

Subject: Re: Justify your opinion on the ECB Vs CBC in terms of security Message:

Both Electronic Code Book and Cipher Block Chaining are algorithms which is used to encrypt one block of text at a time. This is also called as block cipher.

Electronic code book(ECB):

  • The electronic code book is a very basic encryption algorithm which is mainly used for encrypting small data.
  • The electronic code book is not secure than the cipher block chaining.
  • It is because the ECB algorithm encrypts a plain text by converting it into a sub block and then into a cipher text using a key. This results in producing the same cipher text for two plain texts if the plain texts are the same. The decryption process is simple when the same key is used to decrypt the sub block into plain text and combining them finally to get the message.

Cipher block chaining (CBC):

  • The cipher block chaining is advanced form of block cipher which is suitable to encrypt large text.
  • CBC very much secure than the EBC.
  • Because the cipher block chaining algorithm first divides the message into sub blocks of 64 bits and then uses an initialization vector along with the first sub block and a key for encryption. The next encryption is done using the sub block and previous cipher text produced. This result is more secure encryption. The decryption is done using the same process bus uses vector for every decryption of the sub block.

Finally according to to the above mentioned algorithms CBC gains advantage over EBC.

Subject: MSE1 PORTIONS Message:

UNIT 1: Introduction to different logic families: Electrical characteristics of logic gates – logic levels and noise margins, fan-out, propagation delay, transition time, power consumption and power delay product, operation of TTL NAND, ECL and CMOS. 

Numbering system- conversion from one numbering system to another, binary addition, subtraction (1’s and 2’s complement), Simplification and realization of Boolean expressions using basic and universal gates, SOP, POS forms and standard Canonical forms.

UNIT 2: K-map: Introduction, representation, and minimization of 3, 4 and 5 variable functions.

Combinational logic: Half adder, full adder, half subtractor, full subtractor, parallel adder/subtractor, BCD Adder.

Subject: MSE 1 PORTIONS Message:

UNIT 1: Introduction-Definition of Transducer, Classification of Transducers, Advantages and Disadvantages of Electrical Transducers, Transducers Actuating Mechanisms, Resistance Transducers, Variable Inductance Transducers, Capacitive Transducers, Piezoelectric Transducers, Hall Effect Transducers, Thermoelectric Transducers, Photoelectric Transducers

UNIT 2: Strain Gauges-types, Load Cells, Proximity Sensors, Pneumatic Sensors, Light Sensors, Tactile Sensors, Smart Sensors.

Subject: MSE-1 Portions Message:

UNIT-1

Introduction. Why study AI? What is AI? The Turing test. Rationality. Branches of AI. Brief history of AI. Challenges for the future. What is an intelligent agent? Doing the right thing (rational action). Performance measure. Autonomy. Environment and agent design. Structure of Agents. Agent types. Uninformed Search - Depth-first. Breadthfirst. Uniform-cost. Depth- limited. Iterative deepening. Examples. Informed search – Best-first. A* search. Heuristics.

UNIT-2

Game Playing - The minimax algorithm. Resource limitations. Alpha-beta pruning. Constraint satisfaction. Node, arc, path, and k-consistency. Knowledge -based agents.

Lab Programs including the above concepts

Subject: EXAM TIPS Message:

ALL THE BEST for MSEs. 

Your target must be above 20 marks our of 30m and work on it. 

Some tips you may follow which yields better results:

1.  sleep early getup early at least at 5am

2. No or least digital time for external/ entertainment things

3 less or NO gossips

4 make best use of reference section which keep open till10pm and during holidays half days.

5 Read, understand and write in rough sheets without seeing. Give time to digest/absorb.

6. If it is last minute preparation then, No need to learn everything and get confused. instead select most important qns from QB or syllabus prepare completely. That gives confidence. 

7 No cheating. Only handwork, sincerity is the way to SUCCESS. 

8. Keep yourself away from all distractions

8. Good satvic food for body and mind is essential.

9. ALWAYS KEEP IN MIND with affirmation: "Day by day I am working level best towards achieving not only my goals but also PARENTs dreams."

Subject: MSE-1 Syllabus Message:

UNIT-1

Typical transmission & distribution systems scheme: Standard voltages for transmission. Advantage of high voltage transmission, Feeders, distributors and service mains.

Overhead transmission lines: Sag calculation in conductors, Effect of wind & ice on tension & sag at erection, Numerical.

UNIT-2

Line Parameters: Calculation of inductance of single phase, 3 phase lines with equilateral & unsymmetrical spacing. Inductance of composite conductor lines, Numericals

Capacitance: Capacitance calculation for two wire three-phase line with equilateral  spacing.

Subject: Syllabus- LEADERSHIP AND TEAM BUILDING Message:

Dear Student,

PFA of the syllabus for the Subject LEADERSHIP AND TEAM BUILDING

III SEMESTER

(Core Subject – Common for all specialization students)

 

Subject

LEADERSHIP AND TEAM BUILDING

Subject Code

22MBA301

Credits

3:0:0

CIE Marks

50

Total No. of Lecture Hours

39

SEE Marks

100

 

Course Objectives:

1.     To create an orientation about leadership and team building.

2.     To provide scope for the students to acquire the leadership skills and team building skills.

3.     To provide a knowledge base on the types of leadership styles and its application in varied organizational situations.

4.     To make students assess the business situations to build the effective teams accordingly.

 

Course Outcomes: At the end of the course, the students will be able to:

1.     Able to understand the concepts and importance of leadership and team building.

2.     Apply the skills learnt pertaining to leadership and team building skills in organizational context.

3.     To assess the varied organizational situations and apply appropriate leadership styles accordingly.

4.     Identify the business situations and apply the relevant leadership skills to solve it effectively.

 

Unit I                                                                                                                                                         (09 Hours)

Introduction to Leadership – Meaning and definition, Importance of leadership, Leaders v/s Managers, Characteristics of Leaders and managers, Functions of a leaders, Theories of leadership – Contingency Theory, Strategic theory, Personality traits of effective leaders.

Ethics and Culture in Leadership – Meaning of Ethical leadership, Determinants of ethical leadership, Role of culture in leadership, cultural influences on leadership behavior.

 

Unit II                                                                                                                                                          (08 Hours)

Types of Leadership Styles – Types of leadership styles – Autocratic or Authoritarian style, Participative Leadership Style, Benevolent or paternalistic leadership Style, Transactional, and Transformational Leadership styles.

Developing Leadership Skills – Importance of developing leadership skills, designing effective training – Conditions for successful training.

 

Unit III                                                                                                                                                                                             (09 Hours)

Introduction to Team Building and Development – Meaning of Team, Nature of Teamwork, Importance of Teamwork, Characteristics of productive and effective teams, factors contributing to Team development and effectiveness, Mastering and practicing the steps for Team-Building and Development, Team Building Process, Model of Team-Building (Stages in Team Building).

Neuro-Linguistic Programming for Team Building – Meaning of NLP, Benefits of NLP, relevance of NLP for Team building, NLP-Preferred thinking styles (PTS), Effective outcomes of NLP in Team building, NLP – Mirroring techniques.

 

Unit IV                                                                                                                                                                                            (08 Hours)

Building Teams for Globalized Era – Need for teams in global era, Factors influencing the success of global teams, The Leaders’ role in team-based organization, Leader’s action that foster teamwork.

High performing teams – Meaning, characteristics, challenges, training required for high performing teams, The leader-member exchange model and teamwork.

 

Unit V                                                                                                                                                                                       (05 Hours)

Case Study Compulsory question for 20 marks. Review and recap of case studies discussed from Unit I to IV.

 

PRACTICAL COMPONENT:

1. Students to research about a leader of Indian context and International context to prepare a brief report.

2. Students to watch any leadership and team building lesson oriented movie and prepare for a presentation on their learnings.

3. Students to solve case studies pertaining to team development with a role play.

TEACHING PEDAGOGY: The suitable pedagogy to be utilized by the subject teacher

·       Chalk and talk, PPT, A/V, Case Study, Group Discussion, Debate, Role Play, Team Activities, Seminars, Quiz, Guest Sessions, Industry expert sessions, Online Teaching Aid, etc.

TEXT BOOKS:

  1. Team Development and Leadership - Dr. B Rathan Reddy, Jaico Publishing House.
  2. Leadership Research Findings, Practice, and skills – Andrew J DuBrin, Houghton Mifflin, 4th edition.

 

REFRENCE BOOKS:

  1. Leadership in Organizations – Gary Yukl, Pearson Education, 6th Edition 2007.
  2. Effective Leadership – Robert N. Lussier, Christopher F Achua, Thompson Sourthwestern, 3rd Edition, 2007 (India Edition).

Subject: Syllabus- Recruitment and Selection Message:

Dear Student,

PF the syllabus 

III Semester (HR Specialization)

 

Subject

RECRUITMENT AND SELECTION

Subject Code

22MBAHR301

Credits

3:0:0

CIE Marks

50

Total No. of Lecture Hours

39

SEE Marks

50

 

Course Objectives:

 

1.     To facilitate basic understanding of the theory, practice, principles, concepts of Human Capital Management.

2.     To develop an understanding of recruitment, staffing and career management processes and how these elements interrelate.

3.     To enhance students’ effectiveness for optimizing the human resource potential of their organization in order to achieve business and strategic objectives.

4.     To enable students to develop an integrated recruitment and selection strategy in both traditional and modern economy organizational environments.

 

Course Outcomes: At the end of the course, the students will be able to:

 

1.     Identify Knowledge, Skills, Abilities (KSA) of human qualities  required to perform a job analysis and develop  comprehensive job descriptions and job specifications.

2.     Synthesize knowledge regarding the effectiveness of recruitment of  employees.

3.     Identify legal and ethical concerns in selection of candidates and apply their knowledge to develop a professional and competitive hiring plan

4.     Acquire and implement knowledge about induction, orientation, career and succession planning of employees in an organization.

 

Unit I:                                                                                                                                                                                    (09 Hours)

Introduction to Staffing Function: Concepts of Staffing, Factors affecting Staffing, Staffing Process, Staffing models. Strategic staffing, components of strategic staffing.

Human resource planning; Meaning, process of HRP, Benefits of HRP

Strategic job analysis and competency modeling –Meaning of job analysis, Purpose of Job analysis, job description and job specification, Process of Job analysis, Methods of job analysis, competency modeling – Concept.

Job Design –Definition, Modern Techniques, Factors affecting Job Design, Contemporary Issues in Job Designing.

 

Unit II:                                                                                                                                                                                  (09 Hours)

Recruitment - Definition, Importance, Factors affecting Recruitment, Sources of Recruitment  Internal – Notification, Promotion – Types, Transfer – Types, Reference, External – Campus Recruitment, Advertisement, Job Boards – Website/Portals, Internship, Placement Consultancies.

Techniques of Recruitment – Traditional Vs Modern approaches in Recruitment Traditional: Internal Recruitment, On Campus, Employment and Traditional Agency. Modern: Recruitment Books, Internet Recruitment, Service Recruitment, Website and Job Search Engine, Social Recruiting and Candidate Paid Recruiters, head hunting, outsourcing the recruitment function, Pros & Cons of outsourcing recruitment function.

 

Unit III:                                                                                                                                                           (09 Hours)

Selection –Meaning and Definition, Criteria for Selection, Process of selection, Application Blank. Screening – Pre and Post Criteria for Selection, Interview– Types and Guidelines for Interviewer, Types of Selection Tests, Effective Interviewing Techniques.

Current trends in Recruitment and Selection Strategies – with respect to Service, Finance, I.T., Law and Media Industry

Offer letter and Appointment order: Meaning of Offer Letter, Contents of offer letter, Meaning of Appointment order - contents of appointment order and its acceptance, Bond for minimum service, bond for good conduct.

Joining formalities- Joining day formalities, verification and collection of certificate and mandatory documents (PAN, Aadhar copy, Photos). Facilitating for ID Card, facilitating for opening new bank account, Inducting to work station, providing furniture, stationary, equipment, entering name in the muster roll, opening the personal file etc.

 

Unit IV:                                                                                                                                                                                 (08 Hours)

Induction –Meaning, Types-Formal /Informal, Advantages of Induction, how to make Induction Effective

Orientation & On boarding- Meaning of orientation, designing orientation program, Process, Difference between orientation and onboarding, Designing onboarding program, Socialization- Types and Tactics.

Career and Succession Management: Definition and Meaning, Need for Career and Succession Planning, Career and Succession Planning: Career Stage, Career Management, The 5-Stage Process of Succession Planning.

 

Unit V:                                                                                                                                                                                  (04 Hours)

Case  Analysis - Compulsory question for 20 marks. Review and recap of case studies discussed from Unit I to Unit IV

 

PRACTICAL COMPONENT:

1.     Students to prepare a new paper job advertisement for the post of HR, Marketing, Finance Managers for a reputed IT firm.

2.     Students to conduct a mock interview as an HR Manager for their own classmates as a practice. (Team Activity)

3.     Students to draft an offer and appointment letter for any of the designations of their choice.

4.     Students to conduct a mock induction and orientation for their own classmates. (Team Activity)

 

TEACHING PEDAGOGY: The suitable pedagogy to be utilized by the subject teacher

·       Chalk and talk, PPT, A/V, Case Study, Group Discussion, Debate, Role Play, Team Activities, Seminars, Quiz, Guest Sessions, Industry expert sessions, Online Teaching Aid, etc.

TEXT BOOKS

  1. Gatewood, Field and Barrick (2016), Human Resource Selection, 8th Ed,     Cengage Learning, ISBN-13: 9781305102682
  2. Heneman, Herbert G., III, & Judge, Timothy A. (2009). Staffing Organizations, Sixth Edition. Middleton, WI: Mendota House/McGraw-Hill Irwin.

 

REFERENCE BOOKS

  1. Strategic staffing, Jean M Philips & Stanley M Gully, Pearson prentice Hall. 
  2. Recruitment And Selection : Theories And Practices Dipak Kumar Bhattacharyya, Cengage India , 2016
  3. Armstrong, Michael & Baron Angela. (2005). Handbook of Strategic HRM (1st ed.). New Delhi: Jaico Publishing House.
  4. Ulrich, Dave, Smallwood, Norm. (2011), Top-grading: How Leading Companies Win By Hiring, Coaching And Keeping The Best People. Paramus, New Jersey: Prentice Hall. ISBN: 0735200491

Subject: Syllabus- MANAGEMENT AND BEHAVIOURAL PROCESS Message:


Dear Students,

PF the syllabus of MBP


Subject

MANAGEMENT AND BEHAVIOURAL PROCESS

Subject Code

22MBA101

Credits

4-0-0

CIE Marks

50

Total No. of Lecture Hours

52

SEE Marks

50







Course Objectives:

  1. To help the students in understanding the Importance of management and make them realize the Key characteristics, roles and responsibilities a manager must hold.
  2. To enable students in understanding the different aspects of managerial functions and effective Decision making.
  3. To assist students in understanding the field of organizational behavior and its applications in managing corporate human resources.
  4. To create awareness about group dynamics at workplace and to make them realize how to manage people in organizations with various behavioral tools.

 

Course Outcomes: At the end of the course, the students will be able to:

  1. Demonstrate their conceptual skills, understanding and application of principles and functions of management.
  2. Demonstrate an ability to understand the dynamics of functions of management and offer creative solution to business problems.
  3. Identify key theoretical aspects and practical applications of organizational and individual behavior.
  4. Understand and leverage one’s own traits and OB competencies for success in the modern workplace and in life and develop as a potential organizational leader.

 

FOUNDATIONS OF MANAGEMENT

Unit I:                                                                                                                      (08 Hours)

Management – Introduction: Definition of Management, Nature, Purpose and functions, level and types of Management, Managerial Roles and Skills, Roles of a Manager as stated by Henry Mintzberg, Key personal characteristics for Managerial success, Evolution and various schools to management thoughts, Hawthorne study, Characteristics of 21st century Management Executives.

 

Unit II:                                                                                                                    (08 Hours)

Planning: Meaning and Nature of planning, Types of plans, steps in planning process; MBO, Decision making.

Organizing: Organizing as a Managerial function, Organization Structure-Meaning, Types, Process.

Staffing: Meaning, nature, Importance, elements of staffing process.

Controlling – Control function in management, The basic control process, Types of control, Factors in control effectiveness.

BEHAVIOURAL PROCESS

Unit III:                                                                                                                    (10 Hours)

Organizational Behavior: Introduction to Organizational Behavior, Definition, Historical development, fundamental principles of OB, contributing disciplines, Models of OB, challenges and opportunities, the future of OB.

Individual Behaviors: Introduction, Foundation of Individual behavior:

Personality: Definition, determinants, personality traits, personality attributes influencing OB.

Perception: Meaning, factors influencing perception, Process of perception, perceptual errors

Attitudes: Definition, sources of attitudes, types of attitudes, relation between attitude and behavior.

 

Unit IV:                                                                                                                     (09 Hours)

Motivation: Meaning, Theories of motivation

Leadership: Meaning, styles of leadership, leadership theories, transactional and transformation leadership.

Interpersonal Behavior:

Conflict in organization: Meaning, Types of conflict, Conflict resolution strategies

Stress Management: Meaning, Consequences and Sources, Stress Management, Approaches.

Group development:  Group properties, types of groups, stages in formation of groups.

Unit V:                                                                                                                         (04 Hours)

Case Analysis – Compulsory questions for 20 marks. Review and recap of case studies discussed from unit I to IV

 

PRACTICAL COMPONENT:

1. Students have to collect and summarize the recent trends in Management and present the same.

2. Students have to identify three effective leaders across the globe and evaluate their leadership strategies that made them successful.

 

TEACHING PEDAGOGY:

·       Chalk and talk

·       PPT, A/V

·       Case Study

·       Group Discussion, Debate, Role Play, Team Activities,

 

TEXT BOOKS:

Management:

1. Fundamentals of Management-Stephen P Robbins et all, Pearson Publications, Fifth edition, 2007

2. Management and Behavioral processes – B.Janakiram and Vijay N Rao – Excel Books, 2009

 

Organizational Behaviour:

1. Organizational Behavior - Stephen P Robbins, Timothy A. Judge, Seema Sanghi   Pearson Education, 12th Edition, PHI, 2009.

 

REFERENCE BOOKS:

1. Management-Concepts and Cases-V.S.P.Rao, Excel Books, 2012

2. Management – Stephen P. Robbins, M. Caulter, Pearson, PHI, 9e, 2008.

3. Organizational Behavior - V.S.P.Rao, Excel Books, 2009.

Subject: Case study Message:

CASE SCENERIO:
Roy has been with Company XYZ, a renowned Fintech based in Malaysia, for about nine (9) months and has faced challenges related to the project team, especially software developers. Roy is the leader of a new group. To form a bond with the rest of the team, he had to earn their trust and make them feel comfortable around him. It wasn't always easy for Roy at first because members of this team also had an affinity towards their former boss. While he was aware that he was striving to unite the group, the team proved to be challenging to manage. The laid-back working atmosphere is impeding their capacity to perform their duties; it's tough to get them to finish a task, communicate with other team members, or meet deadlines. When he came to the project's monthly review, he was bombarded by stakeholders for being six (6) months behind schedule. The feedback from the project stakeholders also revealed that there are too many unresolved defects and older bugs that haven't been taken care of. He reacted to the meeting feedback with an immediate team meeting and asked if the team could follow his new restructuring plan to catch up. Nobody responded to his worries or straightforwardly accepted his suggestion.


Roy felt emotionally exhausted and stressed by the scenario, his disappointment, and his wrath at the team's responses. There was no consensus that the group was falling behind in bug tracking because they were not adhering to his plan. He started to lose motivation and feel powerless, as though his efforts were in vain. Roy launched a new project, which ultimately caused him to start making plans to quit the organization. The Project Director, Roy's employer, became aware of Roy's unhappiness and was forced to feel bad for not backing Roy's strategy for overcoming the project's difficulties. When Roy's employer approached him, Roy accepted his offer of support for his approaches and proposition. They attempted to analyze the project schedule and backlogs and identify team dynamics.

Upon reflection, the project director brought in a Scrum Master to help Roy resolve his team's problems and to provide long-term improvements for the project.

Questions 

1.      Elucidate the behavioral problems of the team in this case.

2.     Analyse the role of a Scrum Master to help Roy resolve his team's problems.

Subject: Unit 5 demo Message:

Dear all,

Wish you all a happy and prosperous New Year!

For the topic in unit 5, it requires the hands on experience of the work. Hence you are expected to give demo on the following topics on aws,  to be demonstrated from 2nd to 9th Jan 2024. 

Scenario questions are given in the below. 

1.       Launch three EC2 instances. The computations carried out by the three instances should consist of two phases, and the second phase should be started only after all instances have finished the first stage. Design a protocol and use Simple Notification Service (SNS) to implement the barrier synchronisation after the first phase. – Launch ec2 instances , SNS

2.       Provide the options to choose to allow TCP traffic on port 5005 for connecting to a Q process within your AWS account. Ensure that the configuration allows port 5005 on any host launched with the default security group to be accessible. Explain the specific entries or rules that need to be added to achieve this scenario. – Security Groups.

3.       Demonstrate the deploying  an application using aws ec2. – Deploy app

4.       A company is in the process of migrating their applications to AWS. One of their systems requires a database that can scale globally and handle frequent schema changes. The application should not have any downtime or performance issues whenever there is a schema change in the database. It should also provide a low latency response to high-traffic queries. Provide the detailed steps involved in migrating the application into Cloud. – DynamoDB

5.       Create a table named Student using the API of Dynamodb. Write multiple items , where attributes include USN,name, year of joining and branch. Can you retrieve a subset of Attributes while to use Dynamodb.If yes provide the projection expression to retrieve a particular student’s branch from student table. If no provide reason why you cannot retrieve. – DynamoDB

6.     A web application is hosted in an Auto Scaling group of Amazon EC2 instances. The application will be used globally by users to upload and store several types of files. Based on user trends, files that are older than 2 years must be stored in a different storage class. Provide a cost-effective and scalable solution to store the old files yet still provide durability and high availability. – Auto Scaling Groups

7.       A company is in the process of migrating their applications to AWS. One of their systems requires a database that can scale globally and handle frequent schema changes. The application should not have any downtime or performance issues whenever there is a schema change in the database. It should also provide a low latency response to high-traffic queries. Provide the detailed steps involved in migrating the application into Cloud.- Explore what services of the aws is to used and apply

 

Each one will select the unique statement. Once you choose, please post the number here so that others know that they shouldn't select the same question.

Subject: Viva Questions Message:

1. Use of this keyword

2. Extends and Implements 

3. Dynamic polymorphism

4. base class required for writing javafx application

5. How many threads can you create in a program

6. Difference between join and sleep methods in thread class

7. When can you use number format exception

Subject: Re: Viva Questions Message:
1.This keyword is used to refer to the current instance of the class,also used to differentiate between instance and parameters with common name.
2.Extends keyword is used
To extend the class and use its properties and inherit it's behaviour
3.It is achieved through method overriding
4.Application class serves as the base class ,the main class must extend
 Application to get started
5.The number of threads that can be created is unlimited and it also may depend on the resources or the softwares being used.
6.Sleep is a  static keyword that causes the currently executing thread to sleep for the particular period of time Syntax:sleep(100)
Join is the instance method that wait until the thread dies it joins the current and another thread
7.Number format Exception can be used when you try to convert string type to the integer type

Subject: Re: Viva Questions Message:
1.ans) The this keyword in Java is used to refer to the current instance of the class.

2.ans) The extends keyword is used in Java to indicate that a class is inheriting from another class.

3.ans) Dynamic polymorphism, also known as runtime polymorphism, is achieved through method overriding.

4.ans) In JavaFX applications, the javafx.application.Application class serves as the base class.

5.ans) The number of threads that can be created in a Java program depends on the system's resources, including available memory and the underlying operating system. 

6.ans) join is a method in the Thread class that is used to wait for the completion of another thread. 
sleep is a static method in the Thread class that causes the current thread to sleep for a specified amount of time. 

7.ans) Number Format Exception is thrown when a method that converts a string to a numeric type encounters a string that cannot be parsed as a valid number.

Subject: Re: Viva Questions Message:
1. this keyword: Refers to the current object in Java.

2. extends and implements: extends is for class inheritance, implements is for interface implementation.

3. Dynamic polymorphism: Method call resolved at runtime, achieved by method overriding.

4. JavaFX base class: Application class is the entry point for JavaFX applications.

5. Threads in Java: Depends on JVM and OS limits, but too many can cause issues.

6. join vs sleep: join() waits for a thread to die, sleep() pauses the current thread.

7. NumberFormatException: Occurs when a string can’t be converted to a numeric value.

UNIT - 4 : LINEAR SIGNAL PROCESSING CIRCUITS AND ACTIVE FILTERS (10 Hours)

Op-Amp applications for Signal Processing Circuits: Introduction, peak clipper, dead zone circuit, voltage follower peak detector, sample and hold circuit.

Subject: LAB INTERNALS PORTIONS Message:

Following programs are included for LAB INTERNALS:

1.      We have the Map of Romania. In this map, the distance between various places in Romania is given. If we must reach from one place to another place there exist several paths. Write a Python Program to find the shortest distance between any two places using a A* search algorithm.

 2.      Simulate the smart vacuum cleaner agent that cleans rooms size of n * n. The Agent can move Up, Down, Left, Right.  calculate performance each round.

 3.      Write a program to implement Alpha Beta pruning in Python. The algorithm can be applied to any depth of tree by not only pruning the tree leaves but also the entire subtree. Order the nodes in the tree such that the best nodes are checked first from the shallowest node.  

 4.      Implementation of Tic Tac Toe game here  , the player needs to take turns marking the spaces in a 3x3 grid with their own marks, if 3 consecutive marks (Horizontal, Vertical,Diagonal) are formed then the player who owns these moves get won.  Noughts and Crosses or X’s and O’s abbreviations can be used to play.

 5.      Write a program to implement McCulloch-Pitts algorithms, for realizing the AND/OR/XOR/ANDNOT logic functions.

 6.      Implement the Perceptron Learning single layer Algorithm by Initializing the weights and threshold. Execute the code and check, how many iterations are needed, until the network converge.

PREPARE WELL.

Subject: MSE 2 - PORTIONS_Consumer Behavior_22MBAMM301 Message:

Dear Students,

Please note the portions for MSE-2 as below:

UNIT-2: Individual Influences on Consumer Behavior and CRM 

a) Motivation: Basics of Motivation, Needs, Goals, Positive & Negative Motivation, Rational Vs Emotional motives, Motivation Process, Arousal of motives, Selection of goals. Motivation Theories and Marketing Strategy - Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs, McGuire’s Psychological Motives. 

b) Personality: Basics of Personality, Theories of Personality and Marketing Strategy (Freudian Theory, Neo Freudian Theory, Trait Theory), Applications of Personality concepts in Marketing, Personality and understanding consumer diversity, Brand Personality, Self and Self-Image. c) Perception: Basics of Perception & Marketing implications, Elements of Perception, Dynamics of Perception, Influence of perception on CB, Consumer Imagery, Perceived price, Perceived quality, price/quality relationship, Perceived Risk, Types of risk, how to consumers’ handle risk

(Note: Excluding "Learning" concept from unit-2).

UNIT-3: Case Study will be provided for MSE-2

Subject: URGENT: Final Call for Learning Activity-2 (LA-2) Registration - No More Excuses! Message:

Dear Students,

TIME IS RUNNING OUT, and we are appalled to announce that only half of the class has bothered to register for Learning Activity-2 (LA-2) for the EESD course. This is not just a gentle reminder – this is a stern wake-up call to shake off the lethargy and laziness that seem to have taken root.

LA-2 is not a mere checkbox in your academic journey; it is an opportunity for you to showcase your understanding of the course material, to delve into a real-world CASE STUDY or PROJECT aligned with the EESD syllabus. This is your chance to prove your mettle, and yet, complacency seems to have gripped a significant portion of the class.

Here's a recap of what you need to do, and there's no room for further excuses:

Form Groups:

  • LA-2 requires group efforts – pair up with a fellow student. No solo acts will be entertained.
  • Abstract Submission: A mere 150-word Abstract is all that stands between you and the LA-2 registration. Upload it and make a statement about your commitment.
  • Deadline Extension: Recognizing your apparent disregard for timelines, we are reluctantly extending the registration deadline to 5/2/2024. This is your FINAL chance to get on board.
  • Seminar Dates: a. Progress Report Seminar: 7/3/2024 – Mark your calendars! b. Final Presentation Seminar: 18/4/2024 – Your ultimate chance to shine. Don't let it slip away.

Enough with the lethargy, enough with the excuses. LA-2 is a mandatory part of your academic journey, and your lackadaisical approach will not be tolerated any longer. We expect nothing short of full compliance from each and every student.

Register NOW using the link: https://forms.gle/qfF3YWAHdhUEwnnt6

Remember, your academic success is in your hands, and the choice is clear – rise to the occasion or be left behind.

This is your FINAL CALL. Do not let this opportunity pass you by.

Subject: Portion for MSE 3 Message:

Dear all 

Following are the Fundamentals of SCM portion for MSE 3

Integrated logistics, Integrated logistics information system, barriers to logistic integration and Measures to overcome these barriers.

Sourcing Decision In supply chain– Role of Sourcing, In-house or Outsource – Supplier evaluation and selection, 3rd  and 4thPLs. Ethical sourcing practices. make or buy decision.

Unit IV:                                                                                                                                                           (8 Hours)

Transportation Networks and Sourcing- Role of transportation – modes of transportation and their performance –transportation participants, transportation principle- design options and their trade-offs – Tailored transportation. Ware housing: Role, benefits, types of warehousing, Warehouse strategies, Automation in warehousing.

Subject: Syllabus Message:

Dear studens, 

    kindly find the syllabus for your reference.

Subject

ACCOUNTING FOR MANAGERS

Subject Code

22MBA103

Credits

4:0:0

CIE Marks

50

Total No. of Lecture Hours

52

SEE Marks

100

 

Course Objectives:

1.      To make students understand the need and types of Accounting

2.      To help students understand the mechanisms involved in preparation of final accounts of companies.

3.      To expose students to the tools and techniques of analyzing financial reports of companies.

4.      To expose students to the emerging issues in Accounting.

 

Course Outcomes: At the end of the course, the students will be able to:

1.      Acquire in-depth knowledge of Accounting and prepare books of account such as journal, ledger for a set of business transactions.

2.      Analyze the accounting systems to prepare financial statements and interpret them.

3.      Use Ratio Analysis, Cash flow analysis in interpreting the financial reports of companies.

4.      Study emerging issues in Accounting and apply concepts learnt to demonstrate the understanding of the published reports of business firms and companies and also demonstrate the ability to draw meaningful conclusions about the financial performance of business firms and companies.

 

Unit I                                                                                                                                                    (14 Hours)

Introduction to Accounting: Need and Types of Accounting, Users of Accounting, Concepts and Conventions of Accounting, Double entry book keeping - Classification of Accounts: Personal Accounts, Real Accounts and Nominal Accounts – Principles of Debit and Credit for these three categories - Passing of Journal entries – Writing narrations – Posting of Journal entries to ledger, Trial Balance – Purpose and Importance (Problems on Journal entries, ledger and Trial Balance)

Preparation of Subsidiary books: Maintaining Cash books – Sales books – Purchase Books – Sales Returns – Purchase Returns – Cash Transactions – Credit Transactions, three column cash book. (Problems on Three column cash book)

 

Unit II                                                                                                                                                   (12 Hours)

Preparation of Final Accounts: Understanding Trading Account – Profit and Loss Account – Balance sheet-Preparation of final accounts – both horizontal & vertical form of financial statements. (Theory and basic problems on Final accounts of companies)

 

Unit III                                                                                                                                                  (10 Hours)

Understanding financial statement: Comparative, common size, trend analysis, Ratio analysis, Preparation of financial statements using ratios, Preparation of cash flow statement (only indirect method). (Theory and problems)

 

Unit IV:                                                                                                                                                (10 Hours)

Accounting Standards and IFRS: Need for accounting standards. IFRS and proposed changes in Indian Accounting Standards

Emerging issues in Accounting: Corporate Governance and the clause 49 of the listing agreement, Human Resource Accounting, Forensic Accounting, Window Dressing – Sustainability Reporting. (Only theory)

 

UNIT V                                                                                                                                          (06 Hours)

Case Analysis -Compulsory question for 20 Marks. Review and recap of case studies and problems discussed from unit I to unit IV

(Theory: 40%, Problems: 60%)

Subject: LA2_Case study/course project _10th April 2024, 06.00PM Message:

Dear Students,

Please find attached the format to be followed while writing your report. It is important to adhere to this format, as any deviations may result in the rejection of your report. You must submit the report along with a 5-minute video presentation by 10th April 2024, 06.00PM. With this also find the doc file for report format and the evaluation rubrics.

Format for Report:

  1. Title Page: Include the title of your report, the name of your team, and the date of submission.
  2. Table of Contents: Provide a clear and organized list of the sections and subsections in your report along with their corresponding page numbers.
  3. Introduction: Give a brief overview of the Learning Activity (LA) and its objectives. Explain why this LA is important and how it relates to the course or subject.
  4. Methodology: Describe the approach or methods used to carry out the LA. Include details of any research, experiments, or data collection techniques employed.
  5. Results and Analysis: Present your findings and data collected during the LA. Use tables, graphs, or charts to present your information effectively. Analyze the results and draw conclusions based on your observations.
  6. Discussion: Discuss the significance of your findings and their implications. Compare your results with established theories or previous research in the field. Address any limitations or challenges encountered during the LA.
  7. Conclusion: Summarize the key points of your report and reiterate the main findings. Highlight the overall success of the LA and its contribution to your learning experience.
  8. References: Cite all the sources used in your report, including books, research papers, websites, or any other references consulted during the LA.

Please note that the format provided above is specific to the written report. However, for your PPT and video, you have the freedom to be creative and design them in your own unique way. There are no specific formats for the PPT and video.

For the PPT:

  • Ensure that the content is clear, concise, and visually appealing.
  • Use appropriate headings, bullet points, and visuals to convey your information effectively.
  • Maintain a logical flow of ideas and include relevant images or graphs to support your points.
  • Make sure the text is legible and not overloaded with information.

For the video:

  • Prepare a 5-minute video where your team explains the work carried out for the LA.
  • Clearly present the objectives, methodology, and findings of your LA.
  • Engage the audience through effective communication, enthusiasm, and clarity.
  • Use visuals, props, or demonstrations to enhance the presentation.
  • Rehearse the video beforehand to ensure a smooth and coherent delivery.

Remember, the focus of both the PPT and video should be on effectively communicating your work and findings. Use your team's creativity to make them engaging and informative.

Best of luck with your report and presentation!

Dr Kiran Aithal S

Subject: Exercise Your Right to Vote: Lok Sabha Elections 2024 Message:

Dear Students, 

As the Lok Sabha elections approach on April 26th, 2024, I urge each and every one of you to participate actively in this fundamental democratic process. Your vote is not just a privilege but a powerful tool to shape the future of our nation.

 India, with its diverse culture, rich heritage, and vast population, stands as the world's largest democracy. And in a democracy, the power lies in the hands of the people. Your vote is your voice, your opportunity to elect leaders who will represent your aspirations, concerns, and dreams for a better tomorrow.

 It's easy to feel disconnected from politics, especially as students with busy schedules and pressing academic commitments. However, it's crucial to remember that the decisions made by our elected representatives impact every aspect of our lives, from education and employment to healthcare and infrastructure.

 By casting your vote, you are not just fulfilling a civic duty; you are actively contributing to the future direction of our country. Your vote can influence policies that promote equality, justice, and progress for all citizens. It can hold leaders accountable and demand transparency and accountability in governance.

 I understand that sometimes it might seem like one vote doesn't make a difference, but collectively, our votes have the power to bring about significant change. Every vote counts, and your participation can sway the outcome of an election.

 I urge you to take some time out of your day on April 26th, 2024, to visit your nearest polling booth and cast your vote. Make an informed decision based on the issues that matter to you and the kind of future you envision for India.

 Remember, the right to vote is a hard-earned privilege that millions around the world long for. Let's honor this privilege by exercising it responsibly and ensuring that our voices are heard.

 I have also attached 3 pamphlets which give an insight to the procedure to vote, EVM and documents needed during voting.  

Together, let's shape the destiny of our nation.

Regards
Dr Kiran Aithal S
Dean R&D

Subject: Cast your vote - 26th Apr 2024 Message:

Dear Students,

As the Lok Sabha elections approach on April 26th, 2024, I urge each one of you to participate actively in this fundamental democratic process. Your vote is not just a privilege but a powerful tool to shape the future of our nation.

India, with its diverse culture, rich heritage, and vast population, stands as the world's largest democracy. And in a democracy, the power lies in the hands of the people. Your vote is your voice, your opportunity to elect leaders who will represent your aspirations, concerns, and dreams for a better tomorrow.

It's easy to feel disconnected from politics, especially as students with busy schedules and pressing academic commitments. However, it's crucial to remember that the decisions made by our elected representatives impact every aspect of our lives, from education and employment to healthcare and infrastructure.

By casting your vote, you are not just fulfilling a civic duty; you are actively contributing to the future direction of our country. Your vote can influence policies that promote equality, justice, and progress for all citizens. It can hold leaders accountable and demand transparency and accountability in governance.

I understand that sometimes it might seem like one vote doesn't make a difference, but collectively, our votes have the power to bring about significant change. Every vote counts, and your participation can sway the outcome of an election.

I urge you to take some time out of your day on April 26th, 2024, to visit your nearest polling booth and cast your vote. Make an informed decision based on the issues that matter to you and the kind of future you envision for India.

Remember, the right to vote is a hard-earned privilege that millions around the world long for. Let's honor this privilege by exercising it responsibly and ensuring that our voices are heard.

I have also attached 3 pamphlets which gives an insight to the procedure to vote, about EVM and documents needed during voting.

Subject: LA2 Message:

Dear Students,

 

As a part of the course curriculum and learning activity evaluation students should form a team of 3(Mandatory), Choose a Paper under the domain of Big Data Analytics and the same is to be presented along with report.

Note:  Refer Scopus/web of science/IEEE/Taylor publication etc. 2020 onward technical papers only.

 

Submit the topic along with team on or before 6th  June 2024

 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1CFKBsGOn0urV6yh8O8DaTWgmnD3gxq1VcbaGrc4sBKk/edit?usp=sharing

Guidelines for the presentation:

 

1. Each Team submit PowerPoint presentation based on the paper submitted. It must be an individual effort, though discussions with team mates are allowed.

 

2. The PowerPoint is supposed to be a summary of the paper. So your presentation should cover the following points in a small number of slides:

 

- Title slide which should have the Title and your name.

- Overview of the paper. Explanation of the topic/problem you are covering and why it is important. 

- Explain details of the topic, including issues and challenges.

- Explain how the issues or challenges are addressed.

- Conclusion

 

ps - Include figures if they help explain the concepts.

 

3. Student Groups should present the topic in the class. Presentation not more than 15 min per team.

 

Criteria for evaluation

-Paper selection (3).

-Team work & Presentation quality (4).

-Report Submission (3)

 

 

Report should consist of the following

1. Introduction

2. Problem Statement

3. Implementation details

4. Challenges and issues

5. Conclusion

6. Copy of the base paper

7. References

 

 

The presentations will be scheduled after 17th June 2024

Course Title:      CONTROL SYSTEMS                  

Course Code:  22ECG52

Academic Year : 2024_25    Semester : 5     Batch : 2022_2026   Start Date : 23rd Sept 2024

Course Description:  

This course provides an introduction to linear systems, transfer functions, and Laplace transforms. It covers stability and feedback, and provides basic design tools for specifications of transient response. It also briefly covers frequency-domain techniques. This course includes laboratory experiments on MATLAB platform.

Prerequisite:

  • Ordinary Differential Equations
  • Linear Algebra and Complex Analysis. 
  •  Laplace Transform.

Question 50:
Using Matplotlib, generate a heatmap to represent the confusion matrix of a classification model with four classes. Ensure the heatmap includes a color bar and annotations for the matrix values. (BL3)
Answer:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import numpy as np
confusion_matrix = np.array([[30, 2, 3, 0],
[1, 35, 5, 2],
[2, 3, 28, 4],
[0, 1, 3, 32]])
classes = ['Class A', 'Class B', 'Class C', 'Class D']
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
sns.heatmap(confusion_matrix, annot=True, fmt="d", cmap="Blues",
xticklabels=classes, yticklabels=classes, cbar=True)
plt.xlabel("Predicted Class")
plt.ylabel("Actual Class")
plt.title("Confusion Matrix Heatmap")
plt.show()

Subject: Part A - Q17 and Q18 Message:

Q17-List two key differences between a line chart and a bar plot in Matplotlib.

Ans:- Here are four key differences between a line chart 

1.Data Representation:

Line Chart: Displays data as points connected by lines, commonly used for showing trends over time or continuous changes.

Bar Plot: Uses bars to represent data, ideal for comparing values across different categories.

2.Axes Interpretation:

Line Chart: Both the x-axis and y-axis typically represent numerical data, with the x-axis often showing a continuous variable like time.

Bar Plot: The x-axis usually represents categorical data (e.g., different groups or labels), while the y-axis represents numerical values.

3.Visual Emphasis:

Line Chart: Emphasizes the progression or trend of data over a sequence, making it ideal for time-series analysis.

Bar Plot: Focuses on comparing distinct data points, highlighting differences between categories rather than trends.

4.Suitability for Data Types:

Line Chart: Best suited for continuous data where intermediate values are meaningful and the connection between points is logical.

Bar Plot: Suitable for discrete data, where each bar stands independently, often used to display counts, sums, or averages for categories.



Q18-Explain how a scatter plot in Matplotlib helps in understanding the relationship between two variables.

Ans:- A scatter plot in Matplotlib helps in understanding the relationship between two variables by plotting individual data points on a two-dimensional graph, where each axis represents one variable. Here’s how it helps:


1. Pattern Identification: Scatter plots allow us to see patterns or trends in the data, showing whether there is a positive, negative, or no relationship between the two variables. For example, a positive relationship means that as one variable increases, the other tends to increase as well.

2. Correlation Strength: The density and spread of points can indicate the strength of the relationship. If the points are closely clustered along a line, it suggests a strong relationship, whereas a scattered distribution suggests a weak or no relationship.

3. Outlier Detection: Scatter plots make it easy to spot outliers—data points that are far from the main cluster. Identifying outliers can be important for understanding unusual data behavior or potential errors in the data.

4. Linear vs. Non-linear Relationships: Scatter plots help in determining if the relationship is linear or non-linear. A linear relationship will show points clustered around a straight line, while a non-linear relationship might show a curved or more complex pattern.

Subject: Part-A Q15 and Q16 Message:

15)What is the role of the to_csv() method in Pandas, and how is it used to save a DataFrame to a CSV file?

Ans)The to_csv() method in Pandas is used to save a DataFrame to a CSV (Comma-Separated Values) file. This method allows for exporting structured data to a format that can be easily read by various applications, including spreadsheet software and databases.

Basic Saving:

You can save a DataFrame to a CSV file by specifying the file name. By default, it uses a comma as the delimiter.

df.to_csv('output.csv', index=False) # Saves DataFrame to 'output.csv' without row indices.

16)What is the purpose of using Matplotlib in Python, and how does it help in data visualization?

Ans) Matplotlib is a powerful Python library for data visualization, enabling users to create static, animated, and interactive plots. Its primary purpose is to provide tools for representing data graphically, which aids in analysis and understanding.

Key features include:

Versatility: Supports various plot types like line graphs, scatter plots, and histograms.

Customization: Offers extensive options for modifying plot aesthetics.

Integration: Works seamlessly with NumPy and other libraries, enhancing its functionality.

Publication Quality: Produces high-quality visuals suitable for academic and professional use

Part A Q13: What is the purpose of .loc[] and .iloc[] functions in Pandas?
Ans: While indexing, there could be ambiguity on how the numbers are being sliced. To avoid such ambiguous method while idexing, Pandas provides us with two functions .loc[] and .iloc[].
.loc[] is used for explicit indexing, primarily label-based i.e. accessing values by their names or labels. Whereas .iloc[] is used for implicit indexing, which is integer based i.e. accessing values by their index positions.

- Ayush Anand 1NT22CS044

Subject: 5. Explain how NumPy handles numerical operations on arrays more efficiently than Python lists. Message:

NumPy is faster than Python lists because:

1.Memory Efficiency: It stores data in a compact way, avoiding the extra space that Python lists use for pointers.

2.Vectorized Operations: You can do calculations on entire arrays at once without loops, making it much faster.

3.Optimized C Code: NumPy is written in C, so it runs much closer to the hardware, which speeds up operations.

4.Same Data Type: NumPy arrays have a single data type, so they’re faster to process compared to Python lists that allow mixed types.

import pandas as pd

# Creating a DataFrame with COVID-19 data

df = pd.DataFrame({

    'Country': ['Country A', 'Country B', 'Country C', 'Country D', 'Country E'],

    'Cases': [10000, 5000, 15000, 20000, 2500],

    'Deaths': [500, 300, 1000, 1500, 150],

    'Recovered': [8000, 4000, 13000, 17000, 2000]

df['Mortality Rate'] = (df['Deaths'] / df['Cases']) * 100

7. How does the DataFrame structure in Pandas differ from a Python dictionary?

Sol:

*Structure: DataFrame has rows and columns; dictionary has key-value pairs.

*Data Types: DataFrame can handle different data types across columns; dictionary keys point to homogeneous lists or values.

*Indexing: DataFrames support labeled indexing for rows and columns.

*Operations: DataFrames support advanced data manipulation, filtering, and aggregation.

Example: 

# Dictionary

data = {'Name': ['Alice', 'Bob'], 'Age': [24, 27]}

# DataFrame

import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame(data)

print(df)

8. Describe the purpose of a NumPy array and provide an example of creating a 1D array.

Sol:

Purpose of NumPy Array:

*Stores large, homogeneous data efficiently.

*Optimized for numerical and scientific computations.

*Supports element-wise operations and mathematical functions.

Example:

import numpy as np

arr = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])

Print(arr)

Subject: 6. What is the purpose of the Pandas library in Python? Provide an example of how it is used for data manipulation. Message:

The purpose of the Pandas library in Python is to simplify data manipulation and analysis. It provides easy-to-use data structures, like DataFrames, which make it easy to handle and transform datasets.

Example:

import pandas as pd

data = {'Name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],

        'Math': [85, 90, 78],

print(df)

      Name   Math   Science   Average

0    Alice     85          92            88.5

1    Bob       90           88          89.0

2    Charli    78          79          78.5

In this example, we created a DataFrame, then added an "Average" column by calculating the mean of Math and Science scores. This shows how Pandas makes data manipulation easy and efficient.

Q18) Explain how a scatter plot in matplotlib helps in understanding the relationship between two variables.

A)
A scatter plot is a type of data visualization that displays the relationship between two variables by plotting data points on a Cartesian coordinate system.
Scatter plots are especially useful in identifying patterns, strength of the relationship and outliers.

Pattern detection: By observing the spread and clustering of points, you can notice trends in the data.

Strength of the relationship: The closeness of points to a clear line or curve can help gauge the strength of the relationship.

Outliers: Scatter plots help in identifying any points that are far from the rest of the data. These could indicate unique cases or errors in data collection

Subject: Re: Sample to post: Part A - Q1 Message:


11. How does slicing differ from indexing when working with Pandas DataFrames? Provide a brief explanation. (BL2)


Indexing refers to accessing a specific row, column, or cell in a DataFrame by specifying its label or position. For example, using .loc[] or .iloc[] functions for specific row and column selections.

Slicing allows selecting a range of rows or columns, creating a subset of the DataFrame. It is done using slice notation, e.g., dataframe[start:end], allowing you to get multiple rows or columns in a specified range.

12. Explain the use of the dropna() function in Pandas for handling missing data. (BL2)


The dropna() function in Pandas is used to remove rows or columns that contain missing values (NaN). By default, it removes rows with any NaN values, but it can be customized to remove columns or rows only if all values are NaN. This helps in cleaning the dataset by eliminating incomplete data points.

Subject: Re: Sample to post: Part A - Q1 Message:
19. How can a box plot in Matplotlib be used to identify outliers in a dataset? Provide a brief explanation.
• A box plot shows the distribution of a dataset through its quartiles, highlighting the median and interquartile range (IQR). Data points that lie beyond the "whiskers" (typically 1.5 times the IQR from the first or third quartile) are considered outliers, making it easy to spot unusually high or low values within the dataset.
20. Describe the use of a heatmap in Matplotlib for visualizing correlation between variables.
• A heatmap uses color gradients to represent values in a matrix format, where each cell's color intensity indicates the strength of the correlation between two variables. This allows for a quick visual assessment of which variables are strongly correlated, weakly correlated, or uncorrelated, aiding in understanding relationships within the dataset.

10. Create a DataFrame with COVID-19 data (columns: 'Country', 'Cases', 'Deaths',
'Recovered'). Calculate the mortality rate (Deaths/Cases) for each country and add it as
a new column named 'Mortality Rate'. Display the countries with a mortality rate higher
than 5%.
Answer:
import pandas as pd
data = {
'Country': ['CountryA', 'CountryB', 'CountryC', 'CountryD'],
'Cases': [1000, 2000, 3000, 4000],
'Deaths': [50, 150, 120, 60],
'Recovered': [900, 1700, 2700, 3500]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df['Mortality Rate'] = (df['Deaths'] / df['Cases']) * 100

print(high_mortality_countries)

33. Create a Pandas DataFrame with some missing values. Use the fillna() function to replace the missing values with the mean of the respective columns. Display the original and the updated DataFrame. (BL3)

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Step 1: Create a DataFrame with missing values
data = {
'A': [1, 2, np.nan, 4, 5],
'B': [5, np.nan, np.nan, 8, 10],
'C': [np.nan, 6, 7, 8, 9]
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Step 2: Display the original DataFrame
print("Original DataFrame:")
print(df)

# Step 3: Fill missing values with the mean of each column
df_filled = df.fillna(df.mean())

# Step 4: Display the updated DataFrame
print("\nUpdated DataFrame (missing values replaced with column mean):")
print(df_filled)

Subject: XOR solution with Milti Layer Perceptron Message:

Dear Students,

The solution given in the slide as well as in the Machine learning from Algorithmic perspective is correct for Linear Separability problem

The mistake was : Once the C Neuron fires for the input A=1 and B=0 with C=0.5 which is > 0 , its output (as per the the threshold > 0) is considered as 1

so, when the input of C and D are given to E with the weights 1  and -1 respectively , E = 1xC + -1xD=0.5 = 1x1 -1x0 -0.5 = 1-0-0.5 = 0.5 , so E fires. 

It works fine for all the inputs. Sorry for wasting 20 minutes in this.

-Dr.Vani V

Subject: Syllabus Message:

Subject

ACCOUNTING FOR MANAGERS

Subject Code

22MBA103

Credits

4:0:0

CIE Marks

50

Total No. of Lecture Hours

52

SEE Marks

100

 

 

Unit I                                                                                                                          (14 Hours)

Introduction to Accounting: Need and Types of Accounting, Users of Accounting, Concepts and Conventions of Accounting, Double entry book keeping - Classification of Accounts: Personal Accounts, Real Accounts and Nominal Accounts – Principles of Debit and Credit for these three categories - Passing of Journal entries – Writing narrations – Posting of Journal entries to ledger, Trial Balance – Purpose and Importance (Problems on Journal entries, ledger and Trial Balance)

Preparation of Subsidiary books: Maintaining Cash books – Sales books – Purchase Books – Sales Returns – Purchase Returns – Cash Transactions – Credit Transactions, three column cash book. (Problems on Three column cash book)

 

Unit II                                                                                                                         (12 Hours)

Preparation of Final Accounts: Understanding Trading Account – Profit and Loss Account – Balance sheet-Preparation of final accounts – both horizontal & vertical form of financial statements. (Theory and basic problems on Final accounts of companies)

 

Unit III                                                                                                                                   (10 Hours)

Understanding financial statement: Comparative, common size, trend analysis, Ratio analysis, Preparation of financial statements using ratios, Preparation of cash flow statement (only indirect method). (Theory and problems)

 

Unit IV:                                                                                                                                  (10 Hours)

Accounting Standards and IFRS: Need for accounting standards. IFRS and proposed changes in Indian Accounting Standards

Emerging issues in Accounting: Corporate Governance and the clause 49 of the listing agreement, Human Resource Accounting, Forensic Accounting, Window Dressing – Sustainability Reporting. (Only theory)

 

UNIT V                                                                                                                                          (06 Hours)

Case Analysis -Compulsory question for 20 Marks. Review and recap of case studies and problems discussed from unit I to unit IV

(Theory: 40%, Problems: 60%)
